questions.text: A young woman has an intense fear of cats. She also experiences palpitations, dizziness, and sweating when she comes in contact with the cats. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of ailurophobia which refers to the fear of cats. It is a type of specific phobia.

Phobia refers to excessive fear of a specific circumstance, situation, or object. A specific phobia is a strong and per­sisting fear of a particular situation or an object. To diagnose this condition, the prerequisites are the development of intense anxiety or panic, when exposed to the feared object. 

The main defence mechanisms in phobias include displacement, projection, and avoidance. The DSM-5 includes distinctive types of specific phobia:

  • Animal type - e.g. cats, dogs
  • Natural environment type - e.g. storms
  • Blood-injection­ injury type - e.g. needles
  • Situational type - e.g. cars, elevators, planes
  • Other types - for specific phobias that do not fit into the previous four types

Treatment includes behavioural therapy like exposure-based and systematic desensitization. Pharmacotherapy with benzodiazepines, psychotherapy, or combined therapy directed to the attacks may also be beneficial. 

Other options: 

Option A: Xenophobia is a fear of strangers. 

Option B: Acrophobia is a fear of heights. 

Option D: Cynophobia is a fear of dogs.

questions.text: A patient with impacted wax develops a severe cough while performing the following procedure on him. This is due to stimulation of which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is syringing, usually done for the removal of impacted wax. Reflex cough due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus can occur during this procedure.

Wax is made up of sebaceous and ceruminous gland secretions, hair, desquamated epithelial debris, keratin, and dirt. Factors contributing to the accumulation and impaction of excess wax may be a narrow, tortuous external canal, stiff ear, or obstructive lesions in the canal.

Patients with impacted wax may present with impaired hearing, tinnitus or giddiness. Long-standing impacted wax may ulcerate meatal skin and result in the formation of a wax granuloma.

Wax removal is achieved through syringing or other instrumental manipulation. Hard impacted mass may require prior softening with wax solvents in some cases.

The patient is seated, with the ear to be syringed facing the examiner. The patient wears a kidney tray over his or her shoulder and to collect the return fluid, the patient's head is tilted over the tray. A stream of water from the syringe is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus as the pinna is pulled upwards and backward. The ear canal and tympanic membrane must be inspected and dried with a pledget of cotton at the end of the procedure.

Complications of syringing:

  • Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold
  • Rupture of the tympanic membrane
  • Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation

Contraindications for syringing:

  • Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation
  • Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of the device given in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Multiload Cu250, which is one of the copper-containing IUCDs. Formation of the cervical mucus plug is not the mechanism of action. However, progesterone-containing IUCDs can alter the cervical mucus along with the local effects.

The various mechanisms of action of a copper-containing IUCD are:

  • Preventing sperm motility and viability within the uterine cavity by causing a localized inflammatory response.
  • Provokes uterine contractility through prostaglandin release and increases the tubal peristalsis. The egg moves more rapidly into uterine cavity before the development of chorionic villi and thus is unable to implant.
  • Leucocytes infiltrate the endometrium and engulf the fertilized egg.
  • Enzymatic and metabolic changes in the endometrial tissue interfere with the implantation of the fertilized ovum

Some IUCDs like CuT-380A are effective for up to 10 years. Copper IUDs are helpful for emergency contraception if placed within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

Contraindications for use of copper T include

  • Wilson disease 
  • Sensitivity to copper 
  • Pregnancy or suspected pregnancy 
  • Acute pelvic inflammatory disease or STI at the time of insertion
  • A congenital uterine abnormality that distorts the shape of the uterine cavity making insertion difficult
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • Confirmed or suspicion of uterine or cervical malignancy/neoplasia 
Abnormal uterine bleeding of unknown origin
 
Other options:
Option A: Impair sperm motility - Copper ions released from the device create a toxic environment for sperm, reducing their motility and viability.
Option B: Increase the motility of tubes - The IUD can increase uterine contractility, which may affect overall reproductive tract motility.
Option C: Enzymatic changes to prevent implantation - Copper ions alter the endometrial environment, potentially interfering with implantation.

questions.text: In surgical management of pneumothorax, one of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse. Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved in which of the following ways?
questions.solution:
Pleural adhesion cannot be achieved by pleural diathermy.

Diathermy is a surgical method that uses electrical energy in a controlled manner, causing targeted thermal damage to tissues.

Surgery for pneumothorax can be performed by video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) or as an open procedure (thoracotomy). One of the objectives is to make the visceral pleura adherent to the parietal pleura to contain subsequent leaks and prevent complete lung collapse.

Pleural adhesion is achieved in one of three ways:

  • Pleurectomy: systematically stripping the parietal pleura from the chest wall.
  • Pleural abrasion: a scourer is used to scrape off the slick surface of the parietal pleura.
  • Chemical pleurodesis: usually talc is used and is insufflated into the chest cavity.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female patient presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive hearing loss at higher tones. She also classically complains of difficulty in understanding speech and inability to feel her contact lenses. Audiometric tests were done as follows. What is the diagnosis?

Recruitment - absent
Rollover phenomenon - present
Short increment sensitivity index (SISI) - 16%
Stapedial reflex - absent
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) - Interaural latency of wave V is >0.2ms
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the interpretation of audiometric tests, is suggestive of the diagnosis as Vestibular schwannoma.

Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumour arising from the vestibular nerve due to the abnormal proliferation of Schwann cells. Bilateral vestibular schwannoma is seen in neurofibromatosis type 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. It usually presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive retro-cochlear sensorineural hearing loss at higher tones with poor speech discrimination. 

Tumour growth presents with corneal and facial hypoesthesia (inability to feel the contact lens in the given case) due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve. Involvement of the facial nerve presents as hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, known as the Hitzelbergers sign, and defective taste and lacrimation. Involvement of lower cranial nerves presents as dysphagia, aspiration, voice change, and regurgitation. Rarely cerebellar symptoms may also be seen.

  • Pure tone audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in high frequencies.
  • Speech audiometry shows the roll-over phenomenon.
  • The absence of the recruitment phenomenon is noted.
  • Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) ranges from 0-20%.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) demonstrates a significant delay of >0.2 ms in wave V between the two ears.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

Surgical removal by X-knife, Gamma knife, or Cyberknife is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy has no role. 

Other options:

Option A - Presbycusis is the physiological hearing loss due to old age and usually manifests at 65 years of age. Presbycusis occurs due to sensory, neural, metabolic, and conductive pathologies and presents predominantly cochlear hearing loss patterns. High-frequency hearing loss with tinnitus are the presenting complaints with positive recruitment phenomenon. Additional features of corneal hypesthesia are absent. 

Option B - Meniere's disease, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, occurs due to overdistension of the inner ear with endolymph. It is more common in males than females. It may be unilateral or bilateral. Cardinal features are:

  • Episodic vertigo
  • Fluctuating hearing loss of cochlear type
  • Tinnitus  
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Option C - Noise-induced hearing loss(NIHL) is a preventable cause of hearing loss and is an occupational hazard. NIHL causes damage to outer hair cells more than the inner hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. There is symmetrical hearing loss and shows a cochlear pattern on audiometric tests. The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz, both for air and bone conduction. Speech frequencies are also affected.

Related Pearl: The differences between cochlear and retrocochlear hearing loss

  • Roll over phenomenon absent

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is a spermicidal agent used in contraceptives?
questions.solution:
Nonoxynol-9 is a spermicidal agent used in contraceptives. It acts by disruption of the sperm cell membrane. 

Spermicidal agents are chemical contraceptives as they contain surfactants, such as nonoxynol-9, octoxynol, menfegol and enzyme-inhibiting agents. These are available as:

  • Foam tablets
  • Soluble pessaries
  • Creams
  • Jellies
  • Films 

The spermicidal agent remains effective for 1–2 hours after the application. They are always used along with other contraceptives such as the diaphragm, cervical cap, and condom. When they are used alone, the failure rate is high i.e., 30 per 100 woman-years. 

Chronic use of spermicides can cause vaginal irritation, abrasion, and ulceration. This increases the risk of HIV spread. Hence, spermicidal agents should not be recommended to HIV-positive couples. 

Other options:

Centchroman, also known as ormeloxifene, is a non-steroidal oral contraceptive pill. It offers a combination of weak estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic properties. It inhibits the implantation of the fertilized ovum. It is contraindicated during the first 6 months of lactation, PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, and cervical dysplasia.

Gossypol is a male contraceptive pill. It is a cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia.

Clomiphene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that stimulates ovulation. It mainly acts by blocking the inhibitory actions of estrogen on gonadotropin release from the pituitary gland. It is primarily indicated in the management of infertility.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true with respect to the Little's area?

choices.text: Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.
It is situated at the postero-inferior part of the nasal septum.
Anastomoses of 7 major arteries occur here.

questions.solution:
The correct statement among the following is Option A, Keisselbach's plexus is present in the Little's area.

Little's area:

Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. 90% of bleeds arise from Little's area, where the Kiesselbach plexus is situated on the nasal septum. 

Factors that increase the risk of epistaxis in children when compared to adults, include the habit of nose picking and increased friability of mucosa due to frequent upper respiratory tract infections.

Kiesselbach’s plexus:

Four arteries anastomose at the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum (Little's area) to form a vascular plexus called Kiesselbach’s plexus.

  • Anterior ethmoidal
  • Septal branch of the superior labial
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine
  • Septal branch of the greater palatine

questions.text: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the given image showing abnormal dilation and enlargement of the scrotal venous pampiniform plexus,  like bag of worms is suggestive of a varicocele.

Varicocele is an abnormal dilatation and enlargement of the scrotal venous plexus draining the testis. Left-sided varicocele is more common. Most varicoceles are idiopathic, obstruction of the testicular vein by a renal tumour or nephrectomy is seen in some cases.

The pathogenesis behind varicocele is due to increased blood flow to the testis leading to higher intratesticular temperatures, which inhibits spermatogenesis and results in low sperm count, motility and morphology. Most varicoceles are asymptomatic. Those symptomatic tend to present in adolescence or early adulthood, with a dragging discomfort that is worse on standing at the end of the day. There may be a cough impulse. Additionally, patients may have infertility.

Grades of varicocele
Grade 1 Varicocele only palpable on Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 2 Varicocele palpable without Valsalva’s maneuver
Grade 3 Varicocele is seen on inspection of the testis

Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment. Treatment of symptomatic and young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are:

  • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method )
  • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) 
  • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route

In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate. 

Other options : 

Option a: Hydrocele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. In the case of a primary hydrocoele, as the fluid is collected within a closed sac, a cough impulse is unlikely to be seen. Important positive clinical findings in a hydrocoele are that they are irreducible,  the testes cannot be palpated separately, ability to get above the swelling, and transillumination of the swelling.

Option c : Testicular torsion is the twisting of the spermatic cord and its contents such that the testicular blood supply becomes compromised. It is a surgical emergency and if left untreated, the testes may become gangrenous.

Option d : Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac. It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a myringotome. It is a sharp surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum during myringotomy. 

Other options-

Option A- Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for the removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

 

Option C- MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells with one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Option D- Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula are used for proof punctures (antral lavage). Puncture using the trocar is done in the inferior meatus because this site is easily accessible and safe.

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling, as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is laryngocele.

The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/Valsalva maneuver and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling are suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be divided into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as a distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck.
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele.

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard indicative of a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. CT scan reveals the extent of the lesion.

Treatment: Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and surgical excision is done through an external neck incision for external laryngocele.

Other options:

Option A- Thyroglossal cyst is a midline cystic swelling usually affecting younger children. This swelling moves along with tongue protrusion as the thyroglossal duct is attached to the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue. 

The below image shows a patient with a thyroglossal cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing. 

The below image shows the Zenker's diverticulum on the barium swallow. 

Option D- Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child.

questions.text: A young woman who has recently been on a trekking and camping trip to the Himalayas comes to your clinic with complaints of fever and arthralgia. On examination, you notice facial weakness and a circular expanding annular rash on her right thigh. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has been to the Himalayas presenting with fever, headache, myalgias, facial weakness (facial nerve palsy) and the annular expanding rash (characteristic bull’s eye rash called erythema migrans) is suggestive of Lyme disease.

The causative organism is Borrelia burgdorferi.

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard ticks).

The disease occurs in 3 stages:

  • Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
  • Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
  • Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 

Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Option A: Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache,  and intense conjunctival injection. The classic presentation of severe leptospirosis is referred to as Weil's disease - a triad of haemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury.  Some may present as aseptic meningitis, or pulmonary leptospirosis with scattered alveolar hemorrhage. The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone.

Option C: Scrub Typhus (also known as chigger-borne typhus) is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Option D: Listeriosis caused by Listeria monocytogenes presents as a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting for 1–3 days. It is usually transmitted by eating infected refrigerated meat and soft cheeses. There may be associated myalgias, arthralgias, backache & headache. 

Related Pearl: Arthropod-borne Diseases

Mosquito Malaria, filaria, Japanese encephalitis, dengue, West Nile fever, yellow fever, etc.
Housefly Typhoid, paratyphoid fever, diarrhea, dysentery, cholera, gastroenteritis, amoebiasis, helminthic infestations, poliomyelitis, conjunctivitis, trachoma, anthrax, yaws, etc.
Sandfly (Phlebotomus) Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), oriental sore, sandfly fever, oraya fever.
Tsetse fly Sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis)
Louse Epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, pediculosis
Rat flea Bubonic plague, endemic typhus (murine typhus), hymenolepis diminuta.
Blackfly (Simulum) Onchocerciasis
Reduviid bug (Kissing bug/Triatominae) Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis)
Hard tick Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, Kyasanur forest disease, tularemia, tick paralysis, human babesiosis, Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF)
Soft tick Relapsing fever
Ixodes tick Lyme disease, babesiosis and anaplasmosis.
Trombiculid mite Scrub typhus
House mouse mite Rickettsial pox
Itch mite Scabies
Cyclops Guinea worm disease, fish tapeworm
Cockroaches Enteric pathogens
Sand flea (Tunga penetrans, jigger or chigoe flea) Tungiasis, ulcers in feet/nails.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myocarditis

Infections

Viruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, ECHO, influenza, HIV, cytomegalovirus)

Chlamydiae (e.g.,  Chlamydophila psittaci)

Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, typhus fever)

Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus)

Borrelia (Lyme disease)

Fungi (e.g., Candida spp.)

Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis)

Helminths (e.g., trichinosis)

Immune-Mediated Reactions

Postviral

Poststreptococcal (rheumatic fever)

Systemic lupus erythematosus

Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)

Transplant rejection

Unknown

Sarcoidosis

Giant cell myocarditis

 Morphology

  • The heart in myocarditis may appear normal or dilated; some hypertrophy may be present depending on disease duration.
  • Mural thrombi may be present.
  • Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis.
  • Endomyocardial biopsies are diagnostic in some cases, but not when the inflammation is focal or patchy.
  • Hypersensitivity myocarditis: interstitial infiltrates, high proportion of eosinophils
  • Giant-cell myocarditis: multinucleate giant cells (fused macrophages)
  • Chagas disease: Scattered myofibers by trypanosomes.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: What is this device called?

choices.text: Endotracheal tubes equipped with bronchial blockers

questions.solution:
The image given shows Double-lumen endotracheal tubes –to facilitate lung isolation and one-lung ventilation.

Other endotracheal tubes:

Option A: Armored or reinforced tubes: They are flexible, spiral wound tubes which are reinforced with an embedded coil so as to minimize kinking. They are useful in head and neck surgeries and when the patient is in prone position.

Option C: Ring-adair-elwin type of endotracheal tube.It is preferable for nasal and ophthalmic surgeries because it has a preformed right-angle bend at the level of the teeth so that it doesn’t disrupt the surgical field.

Option D: Endotracheal tubes equipped with bronchial blockers – which can also facilitate lung isolation and one-lung ventilation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department accompanied by police. He came to the police station accusing his daughter of wanting to kill him. The police on investigating the family and the neighbors understood that it was a false accusation. His physical examination is not remarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient thinks that his daughter wants to kill him which is not true. Since the patient appears normal apart from the delusion, the clinical scenario is likely to be of a delusional disorder, more specifically delusion of persecution. 

Delusion is a false belief, that is firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

Other options:

Option B: Illusion is an incorrect perception or misinterpretation of a sensory stimulus. Eg: There is a rope in front of you but you see it as a snake.

Option C: Hallucination: Perception in the absence of any stimulus. Eg: There is nothing in front of you but you can see a snake.

Option D: Cotard syndrome is a condition in which an individual feels like they have lost all possessions and status, including their entire being and all internal organs.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the hospital with complaints of difficulty breathing. Chest X-Ray shows "eggshell" calcification. Histopathology of the lung shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's X-ray and histopathology showing silicotic nodule are suggestive of silicosis.

Silicosis is due to the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica) as seen in individuals employed in sandblasting or rock mining

In simple silicosis, the chest X-ray shows small rounded opacities in the upper lobes. When there is progressive nodular fibrosis, irregular masses >1 cm are seen, referred to as complicated silicosis. When these masses enlarge further, it is called progressive massive fibrosis (PMF). Calcification of hilar lymph nodes leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification

Silicotic nodules are characterized by coalescent nodules of whorled collagen fibres surrounded by a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages as shown below.

Silicosis increases the risk of lung cancer. It also increases susceptibility to tuberculosis as pulmonary macrophages are inhibited from killing the phagocytosed mycobacteria by crystalline silica.

Other options:

Option B: Asbestosis shows ferruginous bodies on histopathology

Option C: Lung hamartomas appear as well as circumcised nodules/masses. They do not show silicotic nodules in histopathology.

Option D: Tuberculosis presents with cavitary lesions in the upper lobes of the lungs. Histopathology reveals caseous necrosis with multinucleated giant cells.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female is brought to the emergency with burns sparing the chest, back, and face but involving both lower limbs circumferentially, genitalia, abdomen, and painful erythema in both palms. The burns blanch on touch. Based on the 2018 ATLS guidelines, what fluid resuscitation plan will you choose? (Patient weight: 50 kg)

ATLS- Advanced trauma life support

choices.text: 2.75L over 8 hours, followed by 2.75L over 16 hours
4.5 L over 8 hours, followed by 4.5 L over 16 hours
6 L over 8 hours, followed by 6 L over 16 hours
9 L over 8 hours, followed by 9 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The given image shows 2nd-degree burns as evident from the moist appearance of the skin, associated with pain and blanching on touch. The total volume of fluid needed is 5.5 liters of which 2.75L is given in the first 8 hours and 2.75L is given in the next 16 hours as indicated by 

Step 1: Calculating % of burns using the Wallace rule of nines

  • This includes only 2nd and 3rd-degree burns.
  • Right lower limb + left lower limb and anterior-posterior lower torso+ genitalia = 18 + 18 + 18 + 1= 55%

STEP 2: Calculating fluid using resuscitation formula for thermal burns

According to ATLS 10th ed. 2018 guidelines, the fluid resuscitation formula for thermal burns is 2ml/kg/TBSA% given IV.

Fluid requirement = 2ml x body weight x TBSA

                          = 2ml x 50 kg x 55 %

                          = 5.5 litres.

One-half of the calculated fluid need is given in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is given over the subsequent 16 hours.

The rate of infusion for IV resuscitation fluid should be as constant as possible; sharp decreases in infusion rates can lead to vascular collapse and an increase in edema.

Superficial (epidermal) burns are excluded from this calculation.

Related Pearl: Wallace's rule of 9

This formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Note:

The goal of resuscitation is to maintain the fine balance of adequate perfusion as indicated by urine output. It is important to understand that formulas provide a starting target rate; subsequently, the amount of fluids provided should be adjusted based on a urine output target of 0.5 mL/kg/hr for adults and 1 mL/kg/hr for children weighing less than 30 kg.

questions.text:
Arrange the following anesthetic agents on the basis of their potency.

Nitrous oxide, Halothane, Isoflurane, Methoxyflurane
questions.solution:
The potency of the inhaled anesthetics given above can be arranged as methoxyflurane> halothane> isoflurane> nitrous oxide. It is due to the change in the agents' minimum alveolar concentration (MAC).

The minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an inhaled anesthetic is the lowest concentration required to prevent movement in response to a defined noxious stimulus in 50% of subjects. It is a measure of the potency of inhalational anesthetics. So, the lower the MAC value, the lower the concentration of anesthetic drug required, implying the drug is more potent.

MAC values (expressed as a '%' of 1 atmosphere) of some anesthetic agents:

  • Nitrous oxide with a MAC value of 104 is the least potent inhaled anesthetic
  • Methoxyflurane – MAC- 0.2 (most potent)
  • Desflurane: 6.0 
  • Sevoflurane– 2.05
  • Isoflurane – 1.28
  • Halothane – 0.75

Related Pearl: Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC)

Minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients. 

MAC of inhaled anesthetics

Anesthetic Agents

MAC

(Potency)

Blood-gas coefficient

(Solubility)
Halothane 0.75  2.4
Isoflurane 1.2 1.4 
Enflurane 1.7 1.9 
Sevoflurane 2 0.65 
Desflurane 6 0.42 
Nitrous oxide 104 0.47 

MAC is an indicator of potency. Lower the MAC, higher is the potency.

Blood gas partition coefficient is an indicator of solubility, which affects the rate of induction and emergence. Lower the B-G coefficient, faster is the induction and emergence. It is not related to MAC/potency.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman conceived after being treated for infertility. Her USG scan is given below. What is her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the twin peak sign which is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twins. This is also known as the lambda sign or delta sign.

In dichorionic twins, the intervening membrane between the twins has 4 layers i.e. 2 chorions and 2 amnions. The placenta protrudes from the base to the space between the 2 amnion layers. This gives rise to the twin peak sign i.e. triangle with the base at placenta and apex in the intervening membrane.

The lambda sign: 

Sonographic assessment of dichorionicity is done by observing the following:

  • Number of placental masses - 2
  • Presence of intervening membrane - twin peak or lambda or delta sign
  • Thickness of intervening membranes ≥ 2mm

The best time of delivery of dichorionic diamniotic twins is 38 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the indications for prophylaxis of opportunistic infections in HIV?
Sl No: Organism Indication
1 Pneumocystis jirovecii  A. CD4+ T cell count <100/μL
2 Toxoplasma gondii  B. CD4+ T cell count <50/μL
3 Histoplasma capsulatum C. CD4+ T cell count <200/μL
4 Mycobacterium avium complex D. CD4+ T cell count <150/μL and endemic area
questions.solution:
The correct pairing among the options is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

Sl No: Organism

Options

 Indication
1 Pneumocystis jirovecii C CD4+ T cell count <200/μL
2 Toxoplasma gondii A CD4+ T cell count <100/μL
3 Histoplasma capsulatum D CD4+ T cell count <150/μL and endemic area
4 Mycobacterium avium complex B CD4+ T cell count <50/μL

 

Following are the NIH/CDC/IDSA 2013 Guidelines for the Prevention of Opportunistic Infections in Persons Infected with HIV

Organism Indication
Pneumocystis jirovecii
  • CD4+ T cell count <200/μL(or)
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis(or)
  • Prior bout of PCP
Toxoplasma gondii
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL(or)
  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL
Histoplasma capsulatum Prior documented disease or   CD4+ T cell count <150μL and high risk (endemic area or occupational exposure)
Mycobacterium avium complex(MAC)
  •  CD4+ T cell count <50/μL(or)
  • Prior documented disseminated disease

 

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman presents with a history of pain in the forearm after falling down the stairs. The plain radiograph is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and radiograph are suggestive of Colles’ fracture.

The radiograph shows a transverse fracture of the radius just above the wrist. The fracture appears extra-articular. In the AP view, the distal fracture fragment is dorsally angulated. This is characteristic of Colles' fracture.  

Displacements that may be seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Dorsal tilt
  • Dorsal shift
  • Lateral tilt (Radial tilt)
  • Lateral shift (Radial shift)
  • Supination
  • Impaction of fragments

The clinical feature includes dinner fork deformity with prominence on the back of the wrist and depression in the front. It is treated by a Colles’ cast, which immobilizes the wrist in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.

Complications:

  • Stiffness of joints: Finger stiffness is commonly seen
  • Malunion - can produce dinner-fork deformity
  • Subluxation of the inferior radio-ulnar joint
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome - Uncommon
  • Sudek's osteodystrophy - Colles' fracture is the commonest cause of this condition in the upper limb.

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius.

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presented with painless swelling on the side of his neck anterior to the muscle. On examination, swelling is soft, cystic, and transillumination positive. How would you manage the patient?

choices.text: Advise a CECT scan of the neck

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a Branchial cyst. In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Branchial cysts arise from the remnants of the second branchial cleft. Normally, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th clefts disappear to form a smooth neck. A persistent second cleft is called cervical sinus (of His) which eventually gets sequestered to form a branchial cyst.

Clinical Features:

  • Swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate.
  • Even though congenital, it is seen in late adolescence and early 3rd decade.
  • Histologically, it is lined by squamous epithelium. The cyst wall shows plenty of lymphoid tissue.
  • It may get infected to form an abscess.
  • FNAC shows cholesterol crystals which are derived from the sebaceous glands in the lining mucous membrane.

Treatment:

  • Treatment is by complete excision, which is best undertaken when the lesion is quiescent.
  • Although the anterior aspect of the cyst is easy to dissect, it may pass backward and upwards through the bifurcation of the common carotid artery as far as the pharyngeal constrictors.
  • It passes superficial to the hypoglossal and glossopharyngeal nerves but deep to the posterior belly of the digastric. These structures and the spinal accessory nerve must be positively identified to avoid damage.
  • In a patient who is older than 35 years, there is a high index of suspicion of a malignant necrotic lymph node, and should be ruled out first before excising the mass.

Other options:

Option A: Excision would be the treatment of choice in a patient who is less than 35 years old
 
Option C: Reviewing after 6 months is not correct for a patient who is more than 35 years old as there is a high degree of suspicion of malignancy.
 
Option D: CT scan of the neck is not a recommended initial screening tool for a branchial cyst.

questions.text:
A patient with Crohn's disease who underwent gut resection has been on TPN for the past 2 weeks. He has now developed jaundice and investigations reveal elevated GGT. Which of the following is the underlying cause of his symptoms?

TPN- Total parenteral nutrition
GGT- Gamma-glutamyl transferase

choices.text: Ascending infection of the gall bladder

questions.solution:
In this patient status post extensive gut resection on TPN for 2 weeks with elevated GGT(Gamma glutamyl transferase) and jaundice has most likely developed cholestasis secondary to reduced motility of the gut and gall bladder. 

The lack of gut stimulation leads to reduced flow of bile and can increase the risk of gall stones and cholelithiasis. This can lead to calculous and acalculous cholelithiasis. This condition can be prevented by early refeeding in patients who can tolerate it.

Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) is defined as the provision of all nutritional requirements by means of the intravenous route and without the use of the gastrointestinal tract. Parenteral nutrition is indicated when energy and protein needs cannot be met by the enteral administration of these substrates.

TPN can be administered either by a catheter inserted in the central vein or via a peripheral line. PICC lines have a mean duration of survival of 7 days.

Other options:

Option A: Fatty infiltration of the liver can cause jaundice but this pathology takes a long time to develop, it is unlikely to cause these symptoms in 2 weeks.

Option B: Infection of the gall bladder can cause cholangitis which presents with fever and right upper quadrant pain. But cholestasis related jaundice is more likely in a patient on TPN.

Option D: Bile duct injury is not common in bowel resection surgeries. It is associated with cholecystectomy surgeries following which they can present as bile leak or minor injuries can cause biliary stricture formation and present as obstructive jaundice later.

questions.text:
Match the following :
Section A Section B
1. Yolk sac tumor A. LDH
2. Dysgerminoma B. Beta-hCG
3. Choriocarcinoma C. AFP
4. Epithelial cell tumor D. CA-125

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase

HCG - Human chorionic gonadotropin

AFP - Alpha fetoprotein
questions.solution:
Out of the given optios, Option B represents the correct answer. 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

Ovarian tumors Tumor marker
1. Yolk sac tumor C. AFP
2. Dysgerminoma A. LDH
3. Choriocarcinoma B. Beta-HCG
4. Epithelial cell tumor D. Ca-125

Endodermal sinus tumor/yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic on histopathology. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor and is used as a tumor marker.

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It does not secrete either male or female sex hormones. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is usually used in monitoring individuals or disease recurrence.

Choriocarcinoma is a type of mixed germ cell tumor. It is highly vascular. Histologically, the tumor shows syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts. It secretes large quantities of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) hormone, which is used as a tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of the tumor. 

Malignant epithelial cell tumors of the ovary secrete CA-125. It is a glycoprotein and surface cell antigen which is secreted by malignant epithelial tumors of the ovary. A level of more than 35 U/mL suggests a malignant and residual tumor and indicates the need for chemotherapy. CA-125 is also raised in abdominal tuberculosis and endometriosis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male smoker with type 2 diabetes mellitus presented with nausea, vomiting, weakness and shortness of breath. He is taking Atorvastatin for high cholesterol and is on regular treatment for diabetes mellitus. Lab tests revealed renal insufficiency, with a serum creatinine level of 2 mg/dL.He was admitted with worsening shortness of breath three days after undergoing intravenous pyelography with Iodixanol. Follow-up lab results showed an elevated serum creatinine level of 7.8 mg/dL and a total protein of 5.3 g/dL. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows >0.5 mg/dL increase in S.creatinine levels within the first 3 days of Intravenous Pyelography using high contrast iodixenol, in a patient with diabetes mellitus and pre-existing renal disease renders the diagnosis of radiocontrast-induced nephropathy very probable. However, further causes of renal impairment had to be excluded. 

Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a 25% or 0.5 mg/dL increase from the baseline value of serum creatinine within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. It occurs due to tubular damage and as a result, the patient develops non-oliguric transient nephropathy.

Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy:

Patient-related:

  • eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration
  • eGFR < 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration
  • Patient conditions that increase the risk:
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Dehydration
    • Congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3–4) and low LVEF
    • Recent myocardial infarction (<24 h)
    • Intra-aortic balloon pump
    • Peri-procedural hypotension
    • Low hematocrit level
    • Age over 70
    • Concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs
    • Known or suspected acute renal failure

Procedure-related:

  • Intra-arterial administration of contrast medium
  • High-osmolality agents
  • Large doses of contrast medium
  • Multiple contrast medium administrations within a few days

Side effects of iodinated contrast material include:

  • Idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction - patient develops bronchospasm and hypotension
  • Dose-dependent side effect – contrast-induced nephropathy seen especially with the use of high osmolar agents

Prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy:

  • IV fluids (isotonic saline or sodium bicarbonate) started 1 hour before and continued for at least 3-6 hours after the procedure
  • Low volume low osmolar contrast should be used.
  • N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure.

Note: In a patient on metformin, having deranged RFT, metformin must be stopped before administering the contrast. Otherwise, it can precipitate lactic acidosis.

Other options : 

Option a : Rhabdomyolysis is a severe life-threatening condition, caused due to skeletal muscle damage. Causative factors include traumatic crush injuries, Muscle ischemia during vascular or orthopedic surgery. Skeletal muscle damage causes excessive release of myoglobin, which acts as an endogenous toxin and can cause acute renal failure. Laboratory features include elevated myoglobin, and creatine kinase. Hematuria on dipstick examination without red cells indicates the presence of myoglobin. Cellular damage in rhabdomyolysis causes increased blood levels of intracellular ions such as potassium and phosphate.

Option b : Acute interstitial nephritis is seen in patients who had recent exposure to medications such as PPIs, NSAIDs, and antibiotics. Laboratory features include eosinophilia, and sterile pyuria. It is often non-oligiuric.

Option c :  Intrinsic acute kidney injury arises due to injury to the tubules, interstitium, blood vessels, or glomeruli. These include but are not limited to acute glomerulonephritis, vasculitis, sepsis, infections, and malignancies.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with gout complains of acute onset redness of the eye as given below which is not associated with pain. On further probing, she gives a history of multiple visits to the hospital with the same complaints. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly female with gout presenting with recurrent acute onset redness of the eye not associated with pain and the image showing a nodule away from the limbus surrounded by redness is suggestive of episcleritis.

Episcleritis is benign, recurrent, inflammation of the episclera, involving the overlying Tenon's capsule but not the underlying sclera. It is more common in women than in men. Causes include a hypersensitivity response to internal streptococcal or tubercular toxins. Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Lyme disease, and the herpes zoster virus can all lead to infectious episcleritis. It is also associated with systemic diseases like gout, rosacea, psoriasis and connective tissue diseases.

Episcleritis is characterized by redness, and mild ocular discomfort described as a gritty, burning, or foreign body sensation.

Clinically, two types of presentations may occur:

  • Simple episcleritis is characterized by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera. The image given below shows diffuse episcleritis:
  • Nodular episcleritis is characterized by a pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by erythema, usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm, and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera, and the overlying conjunctiva also moves freely.

Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compress, and artificial tears. In recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs are used.

Other options:

Option A: Conjunctivitis is a refers to the inflammation of the conjunctival tissue, engorgement of the blood vessels, pain, and ocular discharge, and is classified as acute or chronic and infectious or noninfectious. Clinically it is associated with pain and discharge from eyes and other features based on etiology

Option B: Tenon's cyst or conjunctival inclusion cyst is a benign condition filled with serous fluid and slimy mucous secretions of congenital or acquired origin. The patient presents with swelling near the limbus with no pain or redness. The consistency is cystic to firm, non-tender with no mobility suggesting that the cyst is adherent to the underlying scleral tissue. The image of Tenon's cyst is given below:

Option D: Scleritis refers to an inflammation of the sclera proper. It usually occurs in elderly patients (40-70 years) involving females more than males. It is frequently associated with an underlying systemic inflammatory condition. The patient presents with moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and diminution of vision.

questions.text:
A resident is doing an abdominal examination in a primigravida. Sequentially arrange the respective uses of Leopold's First maneuver, Leopold's second maneuver, Leopold's third maneuver, and Leopold's fourth maneuver in the corresponding order
  1. Determine the degree of descent
  2. Confirmation of fetal presentation
  3. Determine the fetal orientation
  4. Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 4, 3, 2, 1:

Leopold First maneuvre - Determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus

Leopold second maneuver - Determine the fetal orientation

Leopold third maneuver - Confirmation of fetal presentation

Leopold fourth maneuver - Determine the degree of descent

Leopold’s first maneuver (fundal grip) is used to determine which fetal pole occupies the fundus.

Leopold’s second maneuver (lateral grip) can be used to determine the fetal orientation based on whether the back is facing anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly. The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen and gentle deep pressure is exerted. The fetal back is felt as a hard-resistant structure and the fetal limbs are felt as multiple small irregular parts.

Leopold’s third maneuver (Pawlik’s grip) helps to confirm fetal presentation. It is done by grasping the lower part of the maternal abdomen with the thumb and fingers of one hand. The palpation of a hard and round mass indicates that the presenting part is the fetal head. A movable mass suggests that the presenting part is not engaged. If the presenting part is breech, it is felt as a large nodular mass.

Leopold’s fourth maneuver (pelvic grip) helps to determine the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 36 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following clinical method can be performed to diagnose/rule out cephalopelvic disproportion in this pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Muller-Munro Kerr method can be performed to diagnose cephalo-pelvic disproportion.

It is performed by placing the fingertips at the ischial spines' level to note the head's descent. The thumb is placed over the symphysis pubis to note the degree of overlapping.

Inferences: (1) No disproportion- The head can be pushed down up to the level of ischial spines and there is no overlapping of the parietal bone over the symphysis pubis.

2) Slight or Moderate disproportion- The head can be pushed down a little but not up to the level of ischial spines and there is slight overlapping of the parietal bone 

3) Severe disproportion- The head cannot be pushed down and instead the parietal bone overhangs the symphysis pubis displacing the thumb.

Limitations: (1) The method is only applicable to note the presence or absence of disproportion at the brim.

(2) The fetal head can be used as a pelvimeter to elicit only the contraction in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet. The disparity in the relation between the fetal head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid-pelvis, or at pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm

Other options:

Option A: Burns-Marshall maneuver will facilitate delivery of the aftercoming head, only after the fetal umbilicus has been delivered. The baby is first allowed to hang by its own weight. Suprapubic pressure is given towards the sinciput in the downward and backward directions.

After the nape of the neck is visible the ankles of the baby are held with one hand while the other hand is used to guard the perineum. The trunk of the baby is spun in a wide arc in upward and forward directions, with constant traction.

Option C: Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with the other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in a downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus.

The procedure is used only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

Option D: Lovset's Manoeuvre involves rotation of the trunk of the fetus during a breech birth to facilitate delivery of the extended fetal arms and the shoulders.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency after being trapped in a landslide for 3-4 hours. He has multiple rib fractures, pneumothorax, hemothorax, and lab findings of elevated creatinine, creatine phosphokinase, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypocalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of prolonged entrapment, clinical features, and laboratory findings are all suggestive of crush syndrome. 

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery) and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Clinical features:

  • The affected limb is pulseless, red, and swollen
  • In some cases, sensation and muscle power may be lost.

Management of crush syndrome

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules.
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure.
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed.
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis.
  • Aggressive management of the open wound.

Other options:

Option A: Fat embolism is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after a fracture of the long bone or other major trauma. It is usually seen 2-3 days following the injury. Clinical features include tachycardia, rise in temperature, breathlessness, and mild mental confusion. 

Option C: Hemorrhagic shock is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Option D: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures(commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paraesthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intracompartmental pressures.

questions.text: Perforation of oesophagus is managed surgically in all cases except:
questions.solution:
Instrumental perforations in the cervical oesophagus are usually small and can nearly always are managed conservatively.

Indications for surgical exploration in Esophageal perforation-

  • Large septic load
  • Septic shock
  • Pleura breached
  • Boerhaave’s syndrome
  • Perforation of abdominal esophagus

Indications for considering non operative management in Esophageal perforation-

  • Small septic load
  • Minimal cardiovascular upset
  • Confined to mediastinum
  • By flexible endoscope
  • Cervical esophagus

Other options:

Option B:  Boerhaave’s syndrome requires urgent surgical repair due to its large, full-thickness tear and high risk of severe mediastinitis. Conservative management is insufficient for this life-threatening condition.

Option C: Perforation of abdominal oesophagus - Surgical intervention is necessary to repair the perforation and prevent peritonitis. 

Option D: Septic shock indicates severe systemic infection requiring immediate surgical source control. Conservative management alone is inadequate in this critical condition.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic after unsuccessfully trying to conceive. The female partner has no specific complaints. The male partner reports absence of semen during intercourse and cloudy urine afterward. He has a history of diabetes and underwent TURP 6 months ago. What is the underlying mechanism of this complication?

choices.text: Injury to the external urethral sphincter
Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis
Over use of coagulating diathermy during the procedure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario above suggests the patient has retrograde ejaculation. The most likely mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. 

Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). 

Other complications of TURP include the following: 

  • Perforation of the bladder
  • Sepsis
  • Incontinence: Occurs due to damage of external sphincter mechanism
  • Urethral stricture: Clumsy/prolonged catheterization
  • TURP syndrome/water intoxication: Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia, and hemolysis. 

Other options:

Option A: Injury to the external urethral sphincter causes incontinence following TURP. 

Option B: Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis causes erectile impotence. 

Option C: Overuse of coagulating diathermy following TURP causes bladder neck contracture.

questions.text: The following abnormality on a JVP waveform can be seen in ________
questions.solution:
The given waveform shows a Cannon ‘a’ wave seen in ventricular tachycardia.

It occurs since atria contract against a closed tricuspid valve in ventricular tachycardia.

JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure.

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

A normal tracing of the jugular venous pulse is given below:

Other options :

Option a : Cardiac tamponade on JVP tracing, characteristically shows a prominent x-descent and absent y-descent.

The image of JVP in cardiac tamponade is given below:

Option c: Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent, as shown below.

Option d : Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave, as shown below.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and pain for 6 months over the upper tibia. His radiographic image is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young boy having gradually progressive pain and swelling and the radiographic image showing a well-defined lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim are most suggestive of Brodie's abscess.

Brodie's abscess is a localized form of subacute osteomyelitis that occurs most often in the long bones of the lower extremities of young adults. The organism most involved would be Staphylococcus aureus. It usually presents with intermittent pain that lasts long and local tenderness over the affected area.

Treatment:

  • Immobilization and antibiotics (flucloxacillin and fusidic acid) intravenous for 4-5 days, followed by oral administration for another 6 weeks; healing may take up to 12 months
  • Curettage is needed if the X-rays show no healing after conservative management.
  • Curettage is also done along with open biopsy in doubtful cases.

All of the given conditions may present with a history of swelling and pain. However, the differentiating features of each of the given conditions are as follows:

Condition Age group Radiographic findings
Brodie's abscess

Children, adolescents

 A lytic lesion with a dense sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Osteosarcoma Children, adolescents, and seventh decade Periosteal reaction leading to sunray appearance and Codman triangle
Osteoclastoma 20-40 years A lytic lesion with a thin sclerotic rim, minimal periosteal reaction
Ewing's sarcoma 10-20 years Periosteal reaction leading to onion peel appearance

questions.text: In a patient with low probability of pulmonary embolism, which of the following should be the initial investigation?
questions.solution:
In a patient wiht low probability of pulmonary embolism, the initial investigation should be measurement of D-dimer levels.

In a patient with high probability of pulmonary embolism, the initial investigation is CT pulmonary angiography.

The following algorithm guides in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient with low and intermediate probability of PE.

The following algorithm guides in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient with high probability of PE.

questions.text: A child presents with a history of fever, cough, and tachypnea. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image show consolidation suggestive of pneumonia.

In lobar pneumonia, the infection develops within the distal airspaces. It spreads via the collateral air drift and produces homogenous opacification of complete or partial lung segments. The airways remain patent as they are not primarily involved. Patent bronchi may be seen within the area of consolidation called air bronchograms. Total resolution of the opacification occurs within 4-6 weeks.

The most common organism implicated in community-acquired adult bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Other options:

Option A: Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is a hypersensitivity reaction involving the major airways. It is most commonly seen in patients with longstanding asthma. It can also be associated with cystic fibrosis. The chest X-ray shows the finger-in-glove appearance / gloved finger appearance of Simon (shown in the image below).

 

Option B: Pneumatoceles are shaggy thin-walled cavities that are seen on chest X-ray. Pneumatoceles can be seen in respiratory tract infections and are most often caused by S. aureus in children and P. jirovecii in immunocompromised adults. It is shown below.

 

Option C: Pneumothorax is air in the pleural space that is often caused by trauma. It can be seen in the chest X-ray as an area void of lung vascularity and a thin white line of visceral pleura that is separated from the parietal pleura by air.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with a history of abnormal jerking movements starting in his left hand and progressively involving the entire arm. Afterward, he experienced weakness and difficulty moving the left arm for about an hour. He has had two similar episodes in the past, and his father has a history of epilepsy. What is the first-line drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes Jacksonian march followed by Todd’s palsy. These are characteristics of a focal seizure. Among the given drugs, the first-line drug for focal seizures is carbamazepine.

First-line agents in the treatment of focal seizures:

  • Lamotrigine
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Levetiracetam

Related Pearl: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures
