questions.text: Identify the instrument given below
questions.solution:
The given instrument is a Doyen’s mouth gag.

It is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on molar teeth.

Option A: Doyen’s retractor is used to retract abdominal wall in abdominal and pelvic surgeries to expose field of operation.

Option C: Doyen’s intestinal occlusion clamp is used to for resection and anastomosis of intestine in case of

  • Strangulated hernia
  • Accidental injuries to the gut
  • Intestinal growths
  • Gastric/intestinal bypass surgeries

Option D: Joll’s thyroid retractor is a self retaining retractor used in thyroid surgeries to retract skin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the finding given in the CT image is pneumatised superior turbinate.

The superior turbinate is situated posterior and superior to the middle turbinate. It may get pneumatized by one or more cells. It forms an important landmark to identify the ostium of the sphenoid sinus which lies medial to it. Pneumatization is a commonly observed anatomical variation of the lateral nasal wall.

It can give rise to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, headache, epistaxis, anosmia, and postnasal drainage. In addition, it predisposes an individual to sinusitis by disrupting the mucociliary clearance and thereby affecting sinus drainage. It is usually an incidental finding on radiological examination and a CT scan helps in the diagnosis.

Superior turbinate pneumatization is mostly asymptomatic and does not require any treatment. However, when symptoms do occur, surgical techniques like outfracture, crushing, radio-frequency ablation, turbinoplasty, and microdebrider surgery may be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Pneumatization of middle turbinate leads to an enlarged middle turbinate which is ballooned out, this is called concha bullosa. 

The CT image shown below depicts concha bullosa.

Option C: Onodi cell is a posterior ethmoidal cell that may grow posteriorly, either by the side of the sphenoid sinus or superior to it. Onodi cell is surgically important as the optic nerve may be related to its lateral wall. 

A CT image of an onodi cell is shown below.

Option D: Haller cells are air cells situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. They are pneumatized from anterior or posterior ethmoid cells. Enlargement of haller cells may lead to maxillary sinusitis as it may encroach the ethmoid infundibulum, impeding draining of the maxillary sinus.

A CT image of a haller cell is shown below.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was brought to the emergency department by her husband after a suspected suicide attempt by drug overdose. She is experiencing seizures and difficulty breathing. On examination, she has a fever, a heart rate of 186 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mmHg. Additionally, she has a dry mouth and dilated pupils. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.1, bicarbonate at 14 mmol/L, and pCO2 at 30 mm Hg. The ECG findings are also provided. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient having seizures, metabolic acidosis, tachycardia, hypotension, and pupillary dilatation is suggestive of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) poisoning. The given ECG finding shows wide QRS complex and prolonged QT interval suggestive of Tricyclic antidepressant toxicity. ECG of a patient with tricyclic antidepressant overdose shows three major findings: sinus tachycardia (from anticholinergic and adrenergic effects), prolongation of the QRS complex (from slowed ventricular conduction), and prolongation of the QT interval (from delayed repolarization).

Tricyclic antidepressant overdose:

Clinical features: Seizures, respiratory depression, drowsiness, delirium, Sinus tachycardia, hypotension, prolonged PR/QRS/QT interval, arrhythmias (ventricular tachycardia, fibrillation). Anticholinergic symmptoms like dilated pupils, dry mouth, urinary retention, hyperthermia

Treatment: Oxygen supplementation and IV fluids. Activated charcoal if the patient is brought within two hours of ingestion (unless ileus present), IV sodium bicarbonate (attenuates the TCA-induced cardiotoxicity and metabolic acidosis)

Note: Dialysis is not very helpful in the management of TCA overdose.

ECG of a patient with tricyclic antidepressant overdose shows three major findings, sinus tachycardia (from anticholinergic and adrenergic effects), prolongation of the QRS complex (from slowed ventricular conduction), and prolongation of the QT interval (from delayed repolarization) as given below,

 

Other options:

Option b : Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. It acts through reversible, competitive inhibition of the postsynaptic muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is indicated in the treatment of organophosphate/muscarinic poisoning, in bradycardia, and to reduce salivary secretions. The adverse effects of atropine are due to the antimuscarinic effects, including xerostomia, blurring of vision, photophobia, tachycardia, flushing, warm, dry skin, constipation, urinary retention, anhidrosis, delirium, and coma. Intoxication with atropine results in all the above symptoms along with convulsions, and circulatory collapse due to respiratory failure. Death may occur secondary to respiratory paralysis.

Option c : Lithium Toxicity is associated with symptoms like nausea, vomiting, ataxia, coarse tremors, dysarthria, seizure, and hyperreflexia. There is no specific antidote, and treatment is mainly supportive. In severe toxicity, dialysis is the most effective treatment. It is associated with Ebstein anomaly.

Option d : The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity include atrioventricular junctional rhythm, premature ventricular depolarizations, ventricular bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and second-degree AV blockade. After cardiovascular system, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea i.e., GIT effects are more pronounced. Altered color perception can also be seen in case of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with complaints of blurring of vision and progressive discomfort in both his eyes for the past 1 week. There is an antecedent history of penetrating trauma to his right eye 6 weeks back. Slit lamp examination reveals mutton-fat keratic precipitates in the anterior chamber. Direct ophthalmoscopy shows discrete yellow-white nodules in the fundus. What is the main modality of initial management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis. Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone therapy is the main modality of the initial management of this condition.

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Dalen-Fuchs nodules are depicted in the image below.

The exciting eye shows features of low-grade uveitis such as ciliary congestion, lacrimation, and tenderness. The sympathizing eye is usually involved 4-8 weeks later. It has a prodromal stage with photophobia, ciliary congestion, and keratic precipitates. In the fully developed stage, symptoms of acute iridocyclitis supervene.

Management options for sympathetic ophthalmitis:

  • Pulse intravenous methylprednisolone (up to 1g daily for 3 days) followed by oral prednisolone (1.5 to 2 mg per kg) is required to suppress the inflammation
  • Immunosuppressive agents such as cyclosporin, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and chlorambucil may be used in cases non-responsive to steroids or patients who have severe side effects due to corticosteroid use
  • Enucleation of the exciting eye can be done immediately after the injury if it is not salvageable.

Other options :

Option a : Systemic antibiotics has no significant role in treatment of sympathetic ophthalmitis.

Option c : Enucleation of the exciting eye can be done immediately after the injury if it is not salvageable.

Option d : Intravenous cyclophosphamide may be used in cases non-responsive to steroids or patients who have severe side effects due to corticosteroid use.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the x-ray showing Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae point towards the diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and has a strong association with HLAB27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain. Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis. Examination findings include loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, diminished spinal movements, and decreased chest expansion.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - earliest sign
  • Periarticular sclerosis in later stages 
  • Squaring of vertebrae due to the flattening of normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body is the earliest vertebral change
  • Bamboo spine appearance due to bridging of adjacent vertebrae
  • Wedging of the vertebra, leading to hyperkyphosis

Complications of ankylosing spondylitis include

  • Spinal fractures, the most common site is C5–7 
  • Hyperkyphosis
  • Spinal cord compression
  • Lumbosacral nerve root compression

Treatment consists of maintaining posture and preserving mobility. Pain and stiffness can be controlled with anti-inflammatory drugs. In severe cases, TNF inhibitors are used. Surgery can be considered to correct the deformity.

The image below shows the bamboo spine's appearance:

Other options :

Option b : Paget's disease is a metabolic bone disorder characterized by an increase in bone turnover at localized sites that is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone. A radiograph of the vertebra gives a diffuse and homogenous increase in the vertebral body opacity that is referred to as the ivory vertebra appearance.

Option c : TB spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. 

Option d : Osteopetrosis is characterized by abnormally dense bone with poor or absent medullary canal formation. The skull base is uniformly radio-dense and radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the rugger-jersey appearance.

Related Pearl: Ankylosing Spondylitis VS Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

           DISH         AS
Etiology Idiopathic Autoimmune
Age group Older patients (middle-aged) Younger patients
HLA No evidence of association with HLA-B27 Strong association with HLA-B27
Lab investigations Non-specific and inconclusive High ESR and CRP
Syndesmophytes Nonmarginal Marginal
Radiograph "Flowing candle wax"  "Bamboo spine" 
Disc space Preservation of disc space AS in cervical spine will show ossification of disc space 
SI joint involvement  No involvement (SI joint abnormality generally excludes the diagnosis of DISH)  Bilateral sacroiliitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about cobalt-60?

choices.text: It is used for gamma knife surgery
It is used in high dose-rate brachytherapy

questions.solution:
Cobalt-60 emits beta particles and gamma radiation. It does not emit alpha particles.

Cobalt-60 is a radioactive metal commonly used in medical radiation therapy. Its mode of decay is via beta particles and gamma radiation. The half-life of cobalt-60 is 5.27 years.

Cobalt-60 isotope has traditionally been popular for teletherapy, although this use is decreasing. It has also been used in gamma knife surgeries. A newer use of the cobalt-60 isotope has been in the field of high-dose-rate brachytherapy.

questions.text: A patient with increased blood pressure on evaluation was found to have low serum potassium levels along with an arterial blood gas analysis report showing a picture of alkalosis. A diagnosis of Liddle syndrome is made. Identify the drug which can be used for the treatment of this condition.
questions.solution:
Amiloride is used for the treatment of Liddle syndrome.

Liddle's syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

It is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene. This gene codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. This leads to increased sodium retention and results in a state of pseudo-hyperaldosteronism. The following findings are seen:

  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis
  • Normal-low aldosterone
  • Low renin 

Treatment is with diuretics that directly block the ENaC channels, like amiloride and triamterene. Spironolactone is not effective as it is an aldosterone-receptor antagonist.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby is brought for a facial defect. On examination, the following findings were noticed. The soft and the hard palate are intact. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft lip repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months

questions.solution:
The given clinical image is that of a child with a cleft lip on the left side and soft and the hard palate are intact. The most appropriate management for this patient would be a cleft lip repair at 4-6 months.

Etiology of the cleft lip can include familial, protein and vitamin deficiency, rubella infection, radiation, chromosomal abnormalities, maternal epilepsy and drug intake during pregnancy (steroids/eptoin/diazepam).

Majority of the cases are unilateral and cleft lip alone is uncommon.

The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip repair at 4 to 6 months. 

According to Delaire timing of cleft surgery - unilateral cleft lip alone can be operated in one stage operation and is done at 4-6 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Related Pearl: Timing of primary cleft lip and palate procedures:

Cleft lip alone

  • Unilateral (one side) - One operation at 5–6 months
  • Bilateral (both sides) - One operation at 4–5 months

Cleft palate alone

  • Soft palate - Only one operation at 6 months
  • Soft and hard palate - Two operations
    • Soft palate at 6 months
    • Hard palate at 15–18 months

Cleft lip and palate

  • Unilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 5–6 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months
  • Bilateral - Two operations
    • Cleft lip and soft palate at 4–5 months
    • Hard palate and gum pad with or without lip revision at 15–18 months

Secondary management

  • Hearing, Prophylactic myringotomy, Regular audiological testing - 6–12 months

  • Speech, Velopharyngeal surgery, Speech and language therapy - 18 months

  • Orthodontic management

    - Mixed dentition - 8–10 years
    - Permanent dentition - 14-18 years

  • Excision of maxillary arch, Rhinoplasty - 16+ years

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who had witnessed a terrorist attack has been experiencing frequent intrusive flashbacks and nightmares about the incident. He avoids the places that remind him of it. He is significantly distressed, has difficulty falling asleep, and frequently feels anxious. He has had these symptoms for the last 6 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with re-experiences (flashbacks and nightmares), avoidance of the stimuli associated with the attacks, and hyperarousal (impaired sleep and anxiety) for more than one month is suggestive of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

PTSD is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks - The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring. 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • Avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • Avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state - fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be for >1 month to label it as PTSD.

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. SSRIs may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to stressful situations like financial issues, medical illnesses, or relation­ship problems that develop within 3 months of the stressor. The stressor in adjustment disorder can be of any severity. In adjustment disorder, the individual does not experience intrusive symptoms like flashbacks and nightmares, hyperarousal symptoms, and avoidance symptoms.

Option B: Acute stress disorder presents with the same symptoms as PTSD, but the symptoms usually occur immediately after the trauma and persist for a period of 3 days to up to 1 month after the trauma.

Option C: Persistent complex bereavement disorder occurs after the death of a loved one. Since the death, for 12 months or more, the individual may experience persistent yearning/longing for the deceased, intense sorrow and emotional pain, as well as a preoccupation with the deceased and the circumstances of the death.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of  Van der Hoeve syndrome?
questions.solution:
Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome

Van der Hoeve Syndrome Triad:

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta: A genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones that are prone to fractures.
  • Otosclerosis: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear leading to hearing loss.
  • Blue Sclera: The white part of the eye appears blue or gray due to the thinness of the sclera, revealing the underlying choroidal veins.

Van der Hoeve syndrome primarily involves skeletal and auditory abnormalities, and jaundice is not a characteristic feature.

Icterus may indicate a different underlying pathology, such as liver dysfunction or hemolytic disorders, which should be evaluated separately.

questions.text: Which of the following patients would you diagnose with hypertensive emergency?

choices.text: 50-year-old man with a blood pressure of 162/104 mmHg with no other complaints
47-year-old hypertensive, not responding to treatment with enalapril, thiazide, and beta blockers
55-year-old woman with a blood pressure of 200/140 mmHg with papilledema
60-year-old man with a blood pressure of 188/120 mmHg without any target organ damage

questions.solution:
Patient 3 has a BP of >180/120 mmHg along with papilledema. This is a case of severe hypertension associated with fundoscopic changes (flame hemorrhages, papilledema), which is suggestive of Hypertensive emergency.

Hypertensive emergency is defined as systolic vlood pressure ≥180 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure ≥120 mmHg, associated with acute target organ damage like Papilledema. The syndrome of malignant hypertension is an example of a hypertensive emergency that is associated with an abrupt increase of blood pressure in a patient with underlying hypertension or related to the sudden onset of hypertension in a previously normotensive individual. The absolute level of blood pressure is not as important as its rate of rise.

Pathologically, the syndrome is asso ciated with diffuse necrotizing vasculitis, arteriolar thrombi and fibrin deposition in arteriolar walls. Fibrinoid necrosis has been observed in arterioles of kidney, brain, retina, and other organs. Clinically, the syndrome is recognized by progressive retinopathy (arteriolar spasm, hemorrhages, exudates, and papilledema), deteriorating renal function with proteinuria, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and encephalopathy. 

Other options:

Option A: This patient suffers from hypertension. Since BP <180/110 mmHg, it is not hypertensive urgency or emergency.

Option B: The patient has a blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic. This is a case of resistant hypertension, and it is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudo hypertension (high office blood pressure and lower home blood pressure), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

Option D: The patient has BP >180/110 mmHg and no end-organ damage. This is a case of hypertensive urgency. Target organ damage is absent in hypertensive urgency but is present in a hypertensive emergency. 

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Beta-blockers

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis

Caution in glaucoma

Hydralazine

ACE inhibitors

Enalaprilat

Alpha-blocker

Phentolamine, Urapidil

Centrally acting sympatholytics

Clonidine

Related Pearl: American Heart Association (AHA) 2019 guidelines for hypertension management

According to the AHA hypertension guidelines, 2019, pharmacologic treatment for hypertension is recommended

  • In patients who have ≥10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk, when BP ≥ 130/80 mmHg 
  • In patients who have <10% estimated 10year ASCVD risk when BP ≥ 140/90 mmHg 

 ASCVD - Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease

ASCVD risk is calculated using a calculator provided by the American Heart Association.

 

Lifestyle modifications in the management of hypertension

Intervention Goal Impact on BP
1. Weight reduction The best goal is ideal body weight -5 mmHg
2. Dietary sodium restriction
  • Total sodium - <1.5g/day (AHA 2019 guidelines)
  • Total NaCl (salt) intake - <6g/day
 -5/6 mmHg
3. Enhanced potassium intake 3.5 - 5g/day -4/5 mmHg
4. DASH dietary pattern  high in vegetables, fruits, low-fat dairy products, whole grains, poultry, fish, and nuts and low in sweets, sugar-sweetened beverages, red meats, and saturated and total fat. -11 mmHg
5. Physical activity Aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance and isometric resistance -4-8 mmHg
6. Moderation in alcohol consumption In individuals who drink alcohol - ≤ 2 drinks/ day for men and ≤ 1 drink/ day for women -4 mmHg

DASH – Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension

 

Target BP in hypertensives:

Clinical condition BP Goal, mm Hg
Clinical CVD or 10 year ASCVD risk  > 10% <130/80
No clinical CVD and 10 year ASCVD risk < 10% <130/80
Adults with CKD <130/80
Adults with Type 2 DM  <130/80

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side, increased vocal fremitus, increased vocal resonance, and a dull note on percussion. The patient's plain radiograph is shown below. Which is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with patient having symptoms of  fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough with the chest x-ray showing a bulging fissure sign is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia The likely causative organism is Klebsiella pneumoniae.

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement, cavitation, and pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus). The patient presents with red currant-jelly sputum. A bulging fissure sign is classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging or displacement by copious amounts of inflammatory exudate within the affected parenchyma. Classically, it is associated with right upper lobe consolidation due to Klebsiella pneumonia. Other diseases that manifest a bulging fissure include any space-occupying process in the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.

Classic chest X-ray findings include:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.


The following image shows bulging fissure sign. 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option A : Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C : Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include, Burns infections, Opportunistic and nosocomial infections, Pneumonia in cystic fibrosis, Shanghai fever(severe enteric disease and sepsis), Malignant otitis externa in diabetics, Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis),Ecthyma gangrenosum, Green-nail syndrome.

Option D : Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, non-motile, and non-sporing coccobacillus. H.influenzae causes meningitis, a potentially fatal disease that is most common in children of two months to 3 years old. It also causes laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, suppurative lesions, and bronchitis.

Related Pearl: Empirical Antibiotic Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP)

questions.text:
Which of the following represents the correct match among the following types of shock and their corresponding characteristics?
  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance
A Low Low High
B Low High High
C Low High High
D High Low Low

choices.text: A - Obstructive; B - Hypovolaemic; C - Distributive; D - Cardiogenic
A - Hypovolaemic; B - Obstructive; C - Cardiogenic; D - Distributive
A - Obstructive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Hypovolaemic; D - Distributive
A - Distributive; B - Cardiogenic; C - Obstructive; D - Hypovolaemic

questions.solution:
The correct match is as below:

  Cardiac output Venous pressure Vascular resistance Mixed venous saturation Base deficit
Hypovolemic Low Low High Low High
Obstructive Low High High Low High
Cardiogenic Low High High Low High
Distributive High Low Low High High

Hypovolemic shock - 
It is due to reduced circulating volume. Causes include hemorrhage, dehydration, vomiting, third spacing.

Obstructive Shock -
Leads to a reduction in preload due to mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling. Causes include cardiac tamponade, tension pneumothorax, massive pulmonary embolus, or air embolus.

Cardiogenic shock - 
Due to the failure of the heart to pump blood to tissues. Causes include myocardial infarction, cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, blunt myocardial injury, and cardiomyopathy

Distributive shock - 
Distributive shock is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance leading to vasodilation. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. Causes include spinal shock, anaphylaxis, and septic shock. 

 

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Partial hydatidiform mole has focal villous edema.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Partial moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady presented with polydipsia and polyuria. Her symptoms started soon after a road traffic accident 6 months ago. The daily urinary output was reported to be between 6-8 liters. Clinical investigation showed Na = 130 mEq /L , plasma osmolality = 268 mOsm/L and urine osmolality = 45 mOsm/L. The most likely diagnosis would be _______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows that the patient’s sodium level is below the normal range of 136–146 meq/L. Likewise, both urine and plasma osmolality are also lower than their respective normal ranges of 100-800 mOsm/kg and 275–295 mOsm/kg. These results suggest a disturbance in fluid and electrolyte balance. The most likely diagnosis in this case is psychogenic polydipsia, a condition where excessive fluid consumption occurs without a physiological need for increased drinking.

In psychogenic polydipsia, both urine and plasma osmolality is low due to excessive fluid intake.

 

Condition Plasma osmolality Urine osmolality Plasma Sodium concentration
Central DI High Low Relative Hypernatremia
Nephrogenic DI High Low Relative Hypernatremia
Psychogenic polydipsia Low Low Hyponatremia
SIADH Low High Hyponatremia

 

Other options:

Option A: Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused due to deficiency of ADH secretion. In this condition, the levels of ADH do not increase even after fluid restriction and therefore the urine osmolality will not increase. 

Option C: There is no indication that the patient has acute kidney injury. Patient has polyuria, AKI would have oliguria. And in AKI, his potassium levels would have been elevated.

Option D: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs due to decreased action of ADH. Mutations occur in the V2 receptor or the aquaporin channels and ADH cannot act on them. Therefore, in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, even if the ADH levels are normal, it cannot act on the receptors, and the urine osmolality does not increase after fluid restriction. A simpler way to differentiate between central DI and nephrogenic DI is to measure basal ADH levels and urine osmolality under unrestricted fluid intake conditions. A low urine osmolality with a concurrent elevated ADH level (>1 ng/mL) indicates nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. A low ADH level is suggestive of central DI or primary polydipsia, which can be differentiated on MRI brain.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test showed a restrictive defect with reduced lung volumes. HRCT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. In the given HRCT, there is prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial pneumonia is characterized by a sudden onset of hypoxemia and respiratory distress, following symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection. HRCT shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities and consolidation of the air spaces.

Options B and D: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated with ILD (RB-ILD) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) are more commonly seen in smokers. HRCT shows prominent ground-glass opacities in both these disorders.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: A mother of a newborn noticed vaginal discharge on her sixth-day postpartum. It was explained to the patient that the discharge was called lochia, and it is a normal finding postpartum. Arrange the correct order of the appearance of lochia.
questions.solution:
The correct order of appearance of lochia is rubra-serosa-alba.

Lochia refers to the vaginal discharge resulting from the sloughing of decidual tissue in the early puerperal period. 

Name Colour Timings after delivery Contents
Lochia Rubra Red First few days  Blood, decidua, fetal membranes, Vernix, lanugo, meconium
Lochia Serosa Yellowish/pink After 3 to 4 days WBCs, cervical mucus, micro-organisms
Lochia Alba Pale White After 10th day Decidua, cells, WBC, mucin, cholesterin crystals and fat cells 

The average amount of discharge for the first week is 250 mL and may persist for about 3 weeks.

Malodorous lochia may signify underlying infection. Copious or absent lochia may also indicate infection or lochiometra. The persistence of lochia rubra beyond the normal limit may signify subinvolution or retained bits of the conceptus. Prolonged discharge of lochia alba for more than 3 weeks may signify local genital lesion.

questions.text:
Arrange the following colour codes used in triage in the increasing order of priority starting with the least priority.
  1. Red
  2. Black 
  3. Yellow
  4. Green
questions.solution:
Option C is the correct sequence of triage color coding.

2 Black
4 Green
3 Yellow
1 Red

 

Triage is used to classify the priority of treatment. Higher priority is given to victims whose prognosis would be good with simple medical care. Lower priority is given to moribund patients who would have questionable benefits even with medical attention.

Note:

In the event of a disaster, mass casualty or epidemic, hospitals face a significant demand or a surge for healthcare services that often outpaces the supply of available resources. Reverse triage is implemented during these surge periods.

By identifying and discharging low-risk patients, reverse triage allows faster and more efficient treatment of critically ill patients. It also helps minimize mortality and morbidity for the greatest number of patients while treating the largest number of patients in the shortest period of time.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to the OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score.
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of the patient is G4 P1 A2 L1. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.
  • L - Living children

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins will be expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: A middle aged man presents with progressive atrophy and weakness of upper limb. On examination, he is found to have spasticity of the legs and brisk jaw jerk. MRI shows increased signal in the corticospinal tract. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). 

ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord. It leads to muscle weakness, atrophy, and eventually paralysis. The characteristic findings in ALS include upper motor neuron (UMN) signs such as spasticity and brisk reflexes, as well as lower motor neuron (LMN) signs such as muscle atrophy and weakness.

Conventional MRI is usually normal in ALS and is used to exclude other possible causes although increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI is supportive of the diagnosis of ALS

Other options:

Multiple sclerosis (MS):

  • MS is an autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system.
  • It presents with a wide range of neurological symptoms and signs, such as sensory disturbances, visual changes, and motor deficits.
  • The characteristic MRI findings in MS include multiple demyelinating plaques in different locations.

Subacute combined degeneration:

  • Subacute combined degeneration is typically caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and primarily affects the spinal cord.
  • It presents with symptoms such as sensory disturbances, ataxia, and spasticity.
  • However, the scenario does not mention any signs of vitamin B12 deficiency or specific involvement of the posterior columns, which are typically affected in subacute combined degeneration.

Progressive spinal muscular atrophy:

  • Progressive spinal muscular atrophy (also known as progressive muscular atrophy) is a rare motor neuron disease.
  • It primarily affects the lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy.
  • However, the presence of spasticity and brisk jaw jerk suggests involvement of the upper motor neurons, which is not characteristic of progressive spinal muscular atrophy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese female patient is brought to the emergency room in a dehydrated state. She complains of loose stools for one week. On examination, there is a tender mass in the neck that she says has been present for one year. There are purple striae on her abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

The above clinical features of painful neck mass, diarrhea, and purplish striae on the abdomen indicating cushingoid habitus are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTC are sporadic but they may also be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. 

Most patients present at 50-60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminadases, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne

Diagnosis is by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Total thyroidectomy with bilateral central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors.

Option A- Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the most common thyroid malignancy. Metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread. Many patients are euthyroid and are associated with painless slow-growing mass in the neck. Dysphagia, dyspnea, and dysphonia are seen in locally advanced disease.

Option C- Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is more commonly seen in iodine-deficient areas. They present as solitary thyroid nodules and are associated with a rapid increase in size. Pain is not common but can be seen if hemorrhage occurs into the nodule. Metastasis is bloodborne and lymph node involvement is not seen. FNAC cannot differentiate benign and malignant follicular lesions.

Option D- Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is one of the most aggressive malignancies. It has rapid growth with visceral invasion and distant metastases. Prognosis is very poor and death usually occurs within 6 months.

questions.text: Identify the yoke muscle for the muscle marked below?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the above image is left superior oblique, hence the corresponding yoke muscle will be right inferior rectus. (Its left eye because of the presence of medial septum to the right to eyeball) 

Yoke muscles are contralateral synergists. They are a pair of muscles, one from each eye, which contracts simultaneously during version movements.

Examples are:

  • Right MR and Left LR
  • Right IO and Left SR

questions.text: Absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua will lead to which of the following placental abnormalities?
questions.solution:
The absence of the Nitabuch layer in the uterine decidua leads to the placenta accreta spectrum.

The Nitabuch layer (also known as the fibrinoid layer) is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration where the invading trophoblasts meet the decidua basalis.


This Nitabuch layer is absent in the placenta accreta spectrum (PAS), which is characterized by abnormally implanted, invasive, or adhered placenta.

Risk factors for PAS include associated placenta previa and previous cesarean delivery.

Types of the morbidly adherent placenta:

  • Placenta accreta: Villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta: Villi invade the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta: Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa is a condition in which the placenta is implanted at the lower uterine segment. Patients present with painless, apparently causeless vaginal bleeding after the 28th week. Some of the risk factors include prior cesarean section, suction and curettage, advanced maternal age, and smoking.

Option B: Attachment of the umbilical cord to the membranes is known as velamentous insertion of placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If the leash of blood vessels traverses through the membranes overlying the internal os, in front of the presenting part, the condition is called vasa previa.

Option C: Placenta succenturiata is the presence of one or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis.

questions.text: A patient who underwent surgery for a lipoma 5 weeks back, now presents with a scar at the incision site that is limited to the original wound boundaries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is of a hypertrophic scar as it stays within the confines of the original wound. Hypertrophic scars rise above the skin level but stay within the confines of the original wound and often regress over time.

Accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen during repair may give rise to hypertrophic scar or keloid. The accumulation of excessive amounts of collagen→ raised scars known as a hypertrophic scars. If the scar tissue grows beyond the boundaries of the original wound and does not regress → keloid formation. Formation of excessive amounts of granulation tissue, which protrudes above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization → Exuberant granulation

Inadequate formation of granulation tissue or formation of a scar → wound dehiscence and ulceration. The contraction in the size of a wound is an important part of the normal healing process. An exaggeration of this process gives rise to contractures, which are particularly prone to develop on the palms, the soles, and the anterior aspect of the thorax and are commonly seen after serious burns.

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Features Hypertrophic scar Keloid
Genetic predisposition Not familial Maybe familial - Autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration
Age Children Adolescents. Middle age
Sex Equal in both More common in females
Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surface) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus, respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

 

Other options:

Option A: Keloid- are also raised scars resulting from excessive collagen production, they characteristically grow beyond the boundaries of the original wound. Here, the scar is "limited to the original wound boundaries," so this rules out keloid formation.

Option B: Exuberant granulation- involves excessive granulation tissue that protrudes above the surrounding skin and impedes re-epithelialization. 

Option D: Granulation tissue- is normal in the wound healing process, but it doesn't typically result in a raised scar limited to the original wound boundaries.

questions.text: Identify the type of suturing shown below.
questions.solution:
The image shows the technique of interrupted Sutures. Here each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound.

Option B: Mattress suture produce an accurate approximation of wound edges, especially when the edges to be anastomosed are irregular. The initial suture is inserted as for an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture below.

Option C: Continuous Suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Option D: Subcuticular Sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures. This technique is used in the skin where a cosmetic appearance is important and where the skin edges may be approximated easily.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary function of the cochlea?

choices.text: Detecting rotational movements of the head
Transmitting sound waves to the auditory cortex by converting them into neural signals
Regulating air pressure between the middle ear and external environment

questions.solution:
Transmitting sound waves to the auditory cortex by converting them into neural signals is the primary function of the cochlea.

The cochlea is the spiral-shaped part of the inner ear responsible for hearing. Its main function is to convert sound vibrations into electrical signals (neural impulses) that the brain can interpret as sound. This is done through the hair cells in the cochlea, which detect the sound vibrations and send signals through the auditory nerve to the auditory cortex of the brain.

Other options:

Option A) Maintaining balance and equilibrium are the main functions of the vestibular system, which includes the vestibule and semicircular canals, not the cochlea.

Option B) Detecting rotational movements of the head: The semicircular canals are responsible for detecting rotational (angular) movements of the head. The cochlea, on the other hand, is exclusively involved in hearing, not balance or head movement detection.

Option D) Regulating air pressure between the middle ear and the external environment is a function of the Eustachian tube, which equalizes pressure between the middle ear and the external environment. The cochlea is not involved in air pressure regulation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old unmarried girl comes to the gynecology OPD for vaccination against cervical cancer. Gardasil is administered to her. Which of the following statements about Gardasil is false?

choices.text: It can be administered to both males and females
It is protective against CIN and cervical cancer
It is protective against anogenital warts

questions.solution:
Gardasil is a quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, HPV 11, HPV 16, and HPV 18

  Cervarix Gardasil Gardasil-9
HPV subtypes Bivalent :16,18 Quadrivalent: 6,11,16,18 Nonavalent: 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58
Protects against: CIN, Ca cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Carcinoma cervix Anogenital warts, CIN, Carcinoma cervix,  Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia, Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
Adjuvant 500 mcg aluminium hydroxide with monophosphoryl 225 mcg Al(OH)PO4SO4 500 mcg Al(OH)PO4SO4
Dose 0.5ml 0.5ml 0.5ml
Administration 0, 1-2 , 6 months i.m 0, 1-2, 6 months i.m 0, 2, 6 months , i.m
Administered gender Mainly female. Recently recommended for male also. Female and male Female and male
Ideal Age range: 11-12 years,9-26 years 11-12 years, 9-26 years for both male and female

Females: 11-12 years, 9-26 years

Males: 11-12 years9-15 years - FDA approved

Recent update: Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing, especially at night, accompanied by intermittent muscle spasms. The child has a history of vitamin D deficiency and hypocalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis related to the laryngeal symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a  1-year-old child presenting with recurrent episodes of stridor and wheezing with intermittent muscle spasms, vitamin D deficiency and hypocalcemia is suggestive of Laryngismus stridulus.

Laryngismus stridulus is a laryngeal spasm often triggered by hypocalcemia, which can be caused by vitamin D deficiency. It presents with stridor and can be associated with wheezing and respiratory distress, particularly in infants and children.

  • Stridor: The hallmark symptom is a sudden onset of high-pitched, crowing inspiratory noise.
  • Respiratory distress: Children may exhibit chest retractions and cyanosis during episodes.
  •  Carpopedal spasms (tetany) may occur concurrently, affecting hands and feet.
  • Nocturnal predominance: Episodes often worsen at night or early morning.
  • Brief duration: Typically lasting seconds to minutes, but can be recurrent

The underlying mechanism involves hypocalcemia-induced hyperexcitability of laryngeal muscles. Vitamin D deficiency leads to decreased calcium absorption, resulting in hypocalcemia. This ionic imbalance increases neuromuscular irritability, predisposing to laryngeal spasms.

Other options: 

Option A) Epiglottitis: Typically causes severe respiratory distress, drooling, and high fever, not intermittent muscle spasms or hypocalcemia.

Option B) Vocal cord paralysis: Usually presents with a weak cry and persistent stridor, but is not typically related to calcium metabolism or vitamin D deficiency.

Option D) Laryngeal papillomatosis: Causes benign growths on the vocal cords and presents with chronic hoarseness, but doesn't cause the acute spasms seen in laryngismus stridulus.

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) are correct?
1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
5. No vaccination is needed in case of an emergency splenectomy
questions.solution:
The statements 1, 3 and 4 are correct regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). The risk of developing OPSI is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. 

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI) is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli.

The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Thyroid function tests demonstrate an elevated T4 and normal TSH. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography (USG) is the next best step in evaluating this patient.

A normal TSH level in this patient indicates that he/she is euthyroid. A solitary nodule in a euthyroid state needs further evaluation by USG.

USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Ultrasound findings within a nodule that are considered suspicious for malignancy include:

  • microcalcifications
  • hypervascularity
  • infiltrative margins
  • being hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

Benign nodules are easily compressible whereas malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. Hence, benign nodules are easily deformed on applying pressure while performing USG. The malignant nodules do not deform as easily.

Other Options: 

Option A- FNAC is now only indicated after sonography and evidence of malignant nodules.

Option C- Thyroid autoantibodies are tested to rule out autoimmune thyroiditis in case the thyroid function tests come out abnormal. 

Option D- Radioactive iodine uptake test (RAIU) is only indicated in cases of toxic adenoma, ie, nodularity with features of thyroid toxicity

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of watering eyes and inability to keep eyes opened in a bright room. On ocular examination, the following finding is noted. The finding is a defect in which of the following layers of the cornea?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with photophobia and excessive watering and image showing Haab striae is suggestive of congenital glaucoma. Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in the descemet membrane.

Primary congenital glaucoma refers to abnormally high intraocular pressure (IOP) which occurs as a result of a developmental anomaly of the angle of the anterior chamber. It is not associated with any other ocular or systemic anomaly. It can be classified as follows:

  • True congenital glaucoma (40%) in which intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma (55%), which manifests prior to age 3.
  • Juvenile glaucoma, the least common, in which IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Diagnosis:

  • Corneal haze is due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP.
  • Buphthalmos is a large eye as a result of stretching due to elevated IOP prior to the age of 3 years.
  • Haab striae are curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane.
  • Corneal scarring

Below image shows hazy cornea.

Evaluation under general anesthesia is generally required; IV ketamine lowers IOP to levels lower than those achieved with other agents.

Treatment:

  • Management is essentially surgical.
  • Goniotomy
  • Trabeculotomy
  • Other procedures when angle surgery fails include trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for the past 1 week. Her hands show a typical movement as shown in the image below. She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Physical examination is remarkable for jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with jaundice along with the clip showing a wing beating tremor is suggestive of Wilson's disease with decompensation. The gold standard for diagnosis is liver biopsy.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease, caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase. The characteristics features of wilsons disease include Hepatitis, cirrhosis, behavioral disturbances, wing beating tremor, sunflower cataract and KF rings.

The image below is that of a patient with a KF ring and a sunflower cataract:

Diagnosis:

  • Presence of KF rings
  • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
  • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy - Gold standard
  • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

Trientine and Zinc is the first choice of a drug regimen to be used for treating mild hepatic decompensation in Wilson’s disease.

Other options: 

Option b : Serum ferritin is not used to diagnose wilson disease but rather serum ceruloplasmin is used.

Option c : 24 hour urinary copper excretion is used for diagnosis of wilsons disease but it is not a gold standard investigation.

Option d : Genetic testing is an important part of diagnosis of wilson disease but is not an gold standard investigation. Detection of biallelic pathogenic variants in ATP7B is identified by molecular testing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hematuria and a mass in the left kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of an elderly male presenting with painless hematuria, renal mass, and an axial renal cortical phase CECT image showing renal lesions with irregular enhancement is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC).

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the most common malignant tumor of the kidney. It usually occurs in the age group 50–70 years and macroscopic hematuria is seen in about 60% of the cases. It usually presents with painless gross hematuria, flank pain, or painless flank mass.

Contrast-enhanced CT is the investigation of choice for RCC. On CT, small lesions enhance homogeneously, whereas larger lesions have irregular enhancement due to areas of necrosis. The clear cell subtype may show much stronger enhancement, which is a differential for angiomyolipoma. Still, it is essential to note that macroscopic fat is almost always associated with ossification or calcification.

T1-weighted MRI is often heterogeneous due to necrosis, hemorrhage, and solid components. T2-weighted MRI is hyperdense for clear cell RCC and hypodense for papillary RCC. Thus, a T2-weighted MRI can be used for histological diagnosis. Contrast-enhanced MRI is the investigation of choice for detecting vascular invasion of RCC.

Other options:

Option A: Renal angiomyolipomas are benign tumors that occur sporadically or in association with tuberous sclerosis. The mean age of presentation is 43 years, and there is a female predilection. CT findings show cortical lesions that demonstrate macroscopic fat (less than -20 HU) and absence of ossification or calcification.

Option B: Renal oncocytomas are relatively benign in nature and usually present in the 6th to 7th decade. An important point regarding this tumor is its similarity with RCC, and hence, it is very difficult to differentiate between them preoperatively. A sharp central stellate scar may be seen in one-third of the cases. But RCC may also show this stellate scar appearance in some cases.

Option D: Renal cysts is a broader term that includes the cystic lesions of the kidney. They can be simple cysts that are benign. Complex or complicated cystic lesions needs evaluation and can be malignant. Bosniak classification of renal cysts is given above.

Image showing a simple renal cyst:

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. The findings of immunohistochemistry staining are shown in the image given below. Identify the subtype of breast cancer based on these findings.
questions.solution:
The above image shows immunohistochemistry staining positive for ER, PR, and HER2 receptors, which is triple positive or luminal type B of breast cancer.

Immunohistochemistry staining:

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors; hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor; hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors(50% to 65% of tumors) –Range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas(“triple-negative” or “basal-like”) are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

Defining Features
