questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has had recurrent, severe midface pain, maxillary tooth pain, and eye pain for 3 months. Episodes last 15–30 minutes, occur at night, and are accompanied by nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation. Alcohol or weather changes can trigger the pain. Exam shows cheek tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with a history of recurrent, severe midface pain, maxillary tooth pain, and eye pain for 3 months with episodes lasting 15–30 minutes at night, and accompanied by nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation is suggestive of sphenopalatine neuralgia.

Sphenopalatine neuralgia, also known as Sluder's neuralgia, is characterized by pain in the distribution of the maxillary nerve combined with autonomic symptoms. The involvement of the sphenopalatine ganglion explains the combination of pain and autonomic features :

  • Location of pain: midface, maxillary teeth, and behind the eyes
  • Associated autonomic symptoms: ipsilateral nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and lacrimation
  • Duration of episodes: 15-30 minutes
  • Nocturnal occurrence
  • Triggers: alcohol consumption and weather changes

Other options:

Option A: Trigeminal neuralgia: Typically causes brief (seconds to a few minutes), electric shock-like pains. It's usually triggered by light touch to specific areas of the face, not by alcohol or weather changes. Autonomic symptoms (nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, lacrimation) are not characteristic of trigeminal neuralgia. Trigeminal neuralgia pain doesn't typically wake patients from sleep.

Option C: Occipital neuralgia: The pain in occipital neuralgia is localized to the back of the head, starting at the base of the skull and radiating upwards. It doesn't involve the midface, maxillary teeth, or area behind the eyes and doesn't typically cause nasal congestion or rhinorrhea.

Option D: Glossopharyngeal neuralgia: It causes pain in the throat, ear, and base of the tongue and is often triggered by swallowing, yawning, or coughing. The pain doesn't involve the midface or area behind the eyes and won't cause nasal symptoms or lacrimation.

questions.text: Identify the defect in the ultrasound of a 12 week primigravida.
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image shows absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits resembling the face of a frog points to a diagnosis of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It is one of the earliest detectable congenital defects that can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.  Screening can also be done by serum estimation of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP). The following are the radiological signs seen in anencephaly. 

  • Frog eye sign - Absence of cranial calvaria, prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. 
  • Shower cap sign - The absence of the cranium could lead to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue. This resembles a shower cap giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance. 

The image given below shows frog eye sign seen in Anencephaly.

 

Option B: The image given below shows an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an Omphalocele (asterix). Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. 

 

Option C: The image given below shows cystic hygroma on the neck of a newborn and in the fetus respectively. Cystic hygroma is a congenital multiloculated lymphatic lesion that is classically found in the posterior triangle of the neck. It occurs as a result of sequestration or obstruction of developing lymph vessels. This defect can be picked up in a first-trimester ultrasound. 

 

Option D: The image given below shows a newborn with encephalocele. Encephalocele is caused due to defects in the skull through which the meninges and/or neural tissue herniate. The squamous part of the occipital bone is the most frequently affected bone.

questions.text: Which of the following flaps involves the isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and finally reconnection using microsurgery?
questions.solution:
Free flaps involve isolation of blood supply, disconnection, and then reconnection using microsurgery at the new site. 

Flaps are tissues that bring vascularity as they are transferred with their blood supply.

Types of flaps - 

  1. Random flaps -  Bears no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. It is basically three sides of a rectangle, the length to breadth ratio is less than 1.5:1. 'Delaying the flap' is a process in which cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation. It is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. A second procedure is conducted where it is raised further and finally transferred.
  2. Axial flaps - These are longer flaps. They are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances.
  3. Pedicled/islanded flaps - They can be swung round on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ because of the axial blood supply. The business end of the skin being transferred can hence have the pedicle buried.
  4. Free flaps - In this case the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site 
  5. Composite flaps - Often skin with bone or muscle is transferred with the flap (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively).
  6. Perforator flaps - Tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface. It is a subgroup of an axial flap.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She is nauseous and feels as if the room is spinning.  Altough the symptoms subside after a few minutes, they return when she moves her head. Which of the following is most appropriate to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal.

A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV.

The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver.

Epley's maneuver:

Other options:

Option A: The diagnostic manoeuvre used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV.

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

  1. The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position.
  2. Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.
  3. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.
  4. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.
  5. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus.

Option B: Glycerol test provides information on the cochlear response to the osmotic changes produced by glycerol in the inner ear. It is used in Meneire's disease.

Option C: Calorie test is a test that uses differences in temperature to diagnose damage to the acoustic nerve. This is the nerve that is involved in hearing and balance. The test also checks for damage to the brain stem.

questions.text: A 50-year-old HIV patient presented with a painful lesion, as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing a violaceous growth on the hard palate in an HIV patient is diagnostic of Kaposi sarcoma.

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease. 

AIDS-associated KS is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. Involvement of the oral cavity is most common in AIDS-related KS, but it can be seen in other variants also. Oral KS (OKS) most often involves the hard and soft palate, gingiva, and dorsal tongue with plaques or tumors. The color of the lesions may range from non-pigmented to brownish-red or violaceous.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

There is no definitive cure but KS is highly radiosensitive and achieves complete response in most cases. In AIDS‐associated KS, instituting highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) often (but not always) results in regression of KS. In localized cutaneous KS, excision and cryotherapy can be used. Intra-lesional administration of vinblastine, interferon‐α2b, and imiquimod is also effective.

Other options:

Option A: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) most commonly tends to occur in sun-exposed areas of the face like the nose, eyelid, and other parts of the face. BCC can vary from red, flesh-colored, or white macules or papules, to nodules and ulcerated lesions. The nodular variant is the most common subtype characterized by raised, pearly pink papules with telangiectasias and occasionally a depressed tumor center with raised borders giving the classic “rodent ulcer” appearance.

The image below shows a case of basal cell carcinoma.

Option C: Malignant melanoma primarily arises from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction but may also originate from mucosal surfaces of the oropharynx, nasopharynx, eyes, proximal esophagus, anorectal, and female genitalia. Lentigo maligna, superficial spreading, acral lentiginous, and nodular are the variants of malignant melanoma. It includes pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Amelanotic lesions appear as raised pink, purple, or flesh-colored skin papules. The diagnostic clue for melanoma is the ABCDE criteria.

 

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common skin cancer. UV radiation exposure is the primary risk factor for SCC. Classically, it appears as a scaly or ulcerated papule or plaque that can bleed with minimal trauma, but the pain is rare. It can exhibit in situ (confined to the epidermis) or invasive subtypes. Wide surgical excision including subcutaneous fat is the treatment of choice for SCC.

questions.text: When does the ovary contain the maximum number of oogonia?
questions.solution:
The ovary contains the maximum number of oogonia at the 5th month of intrauterine life. The number of oogonia is estimated to be 7 million.

Oogenesis is the process wherein oogonia differentiate into mature oocytes. It begins before birth. At birth, there are approximately 2 million primordial follicles. At the initiation of puberty, the follicle count is less than 400,000, of which less than 500 are destined to ovulate. Every month, 15–20 follicles are released, out of which one matures to form the ovum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a lump in her left breast. Examination reveals a 6 X 4 cm mass in her left breast and a single mobile lymph node palpable under the mass. Which of the following is the best-recommended surgical treatment modality in this case?

choices.text: Modified radical mastectomy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma of the breast. This patient has breast cancer at T3N1M0 disease which belongs to stage III A. The preferred treatment of choice in such patients is modified radical mastectomy and neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

Pre-operative chemotherapy and postoperative radiotherapy will add to the benefit of the patients. Considerations for treatment of Stage III A and III B disease are summarized in the flowchart as shown below. 

The treatment of breast cancer should be individualized and based on various clinical factors. However, a general idea of it is as follows.

When systemic adjuvant therapy is given before the surgery it is called neoadjuvant therapy.

Early-stage localised cancer(stages 0, I , II) can be treated by mastectomy or breast-conserving therapy(BCT). BCT requires radiation to further improve patient benefit. 

Locally advanced breast cancer(stages IIIA, IIIB) breast adenocarcinoma without distant metastases. It includes breast cancer that fulfils any of the following criteria in the absence of distant metastasis (M0):

  • Tumours more than 5 cm in size with regional lymphadenopathy: T3, N1-3
  • Tumours of any size with direct extension to the chest wall or skin, or both (including ulcer, oedema or satellite nodules): Any T4
  • Presence of clinically fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes, or any infraclavicular, supraclavicular, or internal mammary lymphadenopathy: Any N2 or Any N3

LABC is treated with neoadjuvant chemotherapy + modified radical mastectomy + adjuvant radiation therapy. If ER/PR receptor positivity is present then hormonal therapy is added, and if Her-2/neu receptor positivity is present, then Trastuzumab / Herceptin is added.

Metastatic cancer(stage IV) Treatment of metastatic cancer is aimed at palliating symptoms, improving quality of life, preventing potential disabling complications and attempting to prolong life.

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

Stage IV

Any T, Any N

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OPD with fever, lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge. On examination, her vitals are stable and per vaginal examination reveals lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness. What is the best treatment option for her?

choices.text: Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg with oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 14 days
Single IM injection of ceftriaxone 250 mg  with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 7 days
Oral doxycycline 100 mg BD with oral metronidazole  400 mg for 7 days
Oral ofloxacin 200 mg BD with oral metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever and lower abdominal pain associated with lower abdominal and cervical motion tenderness is suggestive of PID (Pelvic inflammatory disease). The best treatment option for this patient is outpatient treatment with a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days.

Outpatient treatment of PID (according to the current RCOG guidelines):

  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg + oral doxycycline 100 mg BD +/- metronidazole 400 mg BD x 14 days
  • A single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by azithromycin 1 gm per week x 2 weeks.

Treatment of PID in hospitalized patients:

  • Cefotetan 2 g IV 12hourly + doxycycline 100 mg BD orally/ IV  for 48 hours is given followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg +/- metronidazole 400 mg for 14 days
  • Cefoxitin 2 g IV 6hourly + doxycycline 100 mg IV followed by oral route.
  • Azithromycin 500 mg IV 6 hourly for 2 days, then orally for Chlamydia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to you in her second stage of labor. On per vaginal examination, frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges are palpated. What could the fetal presentation be?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the fetus could be in the brow presentation.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

This is a rare presentation that is diagnosed when the portion of the fetal head between the orbital ridge and the anterior fontanel presents at the pelvic inlet.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

  • Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.
  • Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is commonly unstable and frequently converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

Other options:

Option A: Face presentation occurs when the neck is hyper-extended and the chin is the presenting part. The facial features may be palpable on per-vaginal examination. 

Option B: Vertex presentation occurs when the neck is well flexed. A quadrangular area of the fetal skull bound by the bregma, parietal eminence, and lambdoid sutures is palpable on per-vaginal examination.

Option D: Shoulder presentation can occur when the fetus is in the transverse lie. On per vaginal examination during labor, the shoulder is identified by palpating the following parts—the acromion process, the scapula, the clavicle, and the axilla. The characteristic landmarks are
the feeling of the ribs and intercostal spaces (gridiron feel). On occasion, the arm is found prolapsed.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy complains of intense lacrimation, associated with photophobia. On further examination, the following finding is seen in his upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts cobblestone appearance, which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC). No follicular reaction is seen.

  • Vernal conjunctivitis is also called as spring catarrh or warm weather conjunctivitis
  • It primarily affects boys, and the onset is generally from the age of 5 years.
  • It is primarily a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction that is IgE mediated. It also involves type 4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Classical features of conjunctiva in VKC:

Palpebral VKC

  • Cobblestone papillae: upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal VKC: Horner–Trantas spots are white dots consisting of eosinophils and epithelial debris in the limbal area. 

Corneal signs in VKC:

  • Shield ulcers
  • Vernal plaques
  • Subepithelial scarring
  • Pseudo-gerontoxon resembles arcus senilus; it has a cupid's bow outline

Image: Horner Trantas spots

Other options :

Option a : In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.
 

option c : In Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is associated with, white-pinkish nodule in the bulbar conjunctiva.

Option d :  Xerophthalmia is associated with epithelial xerosis and bitot spot in bulbar conjunctiva.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with complaints of a lesion in the lower eyelid. She says that the lesion was initially like a bump and now it is ulcerated. On examination, an ulcerative lesion with raised and pearly white edge is seen in the lower eyelid of the right eye. The biopsy was taken from the lesion and the image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of cell nests. In the periphery of the cell nest, the cells are arranged in the palisading pattern. This is diagnostic of basal cell carcinoma.

Basal cell carcinoma is the malignant tumor of the epithelial cells arising from the basal epidermis.

The strongest risk factor for developing basal cell carcinoma is exposure to UV radiation. Therefore it occurs on the sun-exposed areas of the skin, most commonly on the nose and face.

BCC can be divided into localized and generalized. The localized can be further divided into

  • Nodular and nodulocystic- account for the majority of BCC
  • Cystic
  • Pigmented
  • Naevoid.

Generalized can be further divided into superficial or infiltrative.

The characteristic finding of BCC is the presence of ovoid cells in nests and palisading of the peripheral cells of the nests.

Treatment of BCC includes excision of the lesion or Moh's micrographic surgery.

Other options:

Option A- Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the malignancy of the keratinizing cells of the epidermis. It is associated with exposure to UV radiation and chronic inflammation (chronic sinus tracts, pre-existing scars, osteomyelitis, and burns).

The microscopy of SCC consists of irregular masses of squamous epithelium. They may show keratin production.

Below image shows the microscopic appearance of SCC.

Option B- Marjolin's ulcer- It is a type of squamous cell carcinoma that appears on a pre-existing scar.

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum consists of multiple pink pruritic papules on the skin and mucous membranes with central umbilication. Microscopically it shows the presence of cytoplasmic inclusions in the cells of stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.

Below images show the macroscopic and microscopic appearance of molluscum contagiosum.

questions.text: What is the use of the following instrument?

choices.text: To fix a chalazion during incision and drainage
To separate uveal tissue from sclera during evisceration
To engage the optic nerve during enucleation
To enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR)

questions.solution:
The given image is of a chalazion clamp. It is used to fix the chalazion and achieve hemostasis during the incision and drainage operation (Option A).

The chalazion clamp consists of two limbs like forceps, which can be clamped with the help of a screw. Excessive tightening of the screw can lead to pressure necrosis. The solid blade is placed externally on the skin and the ring-shaped blade is on the inner conjunctival surface.

Other options:

Option B: An evisceration spatula is used to separate the uveal tissue from the sclera during the evisceration operation. It consists of a small but stout rectangular blade with a slightly convex surface and blunt edges attached to a handle.

Option C: An enucleation spoon is used to engage the optic nerve in enucleation. It is identified by the central cleavage present to accommodate the optic nerve.

Option D - A bone punch is used to enlarge the bony opening during dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle.

questions.text: A construction worker got entrapped in a collapsed building. He sustained severe injury over his legs. Which of the following features is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a worker sustaining severe injury over his leg following entrapment is suggestive of crush syndrome. In this condition, hypokalemia is not seen.

Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period. For e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or rubble and after extended use of a pneumatic antishock garment. This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. 

Crush syndrome can result in a systemic reaction due to tissue necrosis. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Management of crush syndrome:

  • Encouraging high urine flow, along with alkalization of urine with sodium bicarbonate to prevent precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules
  • Renal hemofiltration if there is oliguria or renal failure
  • If compartment syndrome is confirmed, then fasciotomy is performed
  • Radical excision of necrosed muscle to avoid sepsis
  • Aggressive management of the open wound

Related Pearl: Acute compartment and Crush syndrome

1. Acute Compartment Syndrome

Acute compartment syndrome is an elevation of the intracompartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis.

Causes: Fractures (70%) and severe soft tissue injuries (30%). Common fractures causing compartment syndrome include tibial diaphyseal (most common), distal radius, and forearm fractures. 

Pathology: Increased pressure in one of the osseofascial compartments due to bleeding, oedema or inflammation. A vicious cycle of ischemia → edema→ ischemia leading to necrosis of the muscles and nerves within the compartment in 6 hours or less. 

Clinical features: Five Ps: Pain, Paraesthesia, Pallor, Paralysis and Pulselessness. 

Management: Fasciotomy to decompress the threatened compartment if the differential pressure (ΔP) goes < 30 mmHg. 

 

2. Crush syndrome 

Crush syndrome is the systemic manifestation of muscle necrosis. It is commonly caused due to prolonged external compression of an extremity. 

Causes: Crush injuries sustained during motor vehicle accidents, earthquakes, mining and other occupational accidents.

Pathology: Underperfusion of muscle causes myonecrosis. When the limb is freed, there is a release of toxic metabolites causing reperfusion injury. Reactive oxygen metabolites create further tissue injury. Free myoglobin can get precipitated in the renal glomeruli. 

Clinical features: The affected limb is pulseless, red, swollen and blistered. Sensation and muscle power may be lost. There can be signs of impaired renal function, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia and hypocalcaemia.

Management: Encouraging high urine output, alkalization of the urine, hemofiltration, radical excision of dead muscles, fasciotomy if there is compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. On examination, bluish discoloration was present over the left 9th and 10th rib area. On asking the patient to take a deep breath, he winced due to pain in the left shoulder region.  Identify the most likely sign elicited here.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette mentions pain over the left shoulder tip on inspiration. This is known as Kehr's sign, seen in splenic trauma.

Blunt trauma to the spleen results in torsion of short gastric vessels in the gastrosplenic ligament leading to subphrenic hematoma. The irritation at the left hemidiaphragm by subphrenic hematoma leads to positive Kehr's sign.

The initial investigation for abdominal injury in patients who are hemodynamically unstable is FAST (focused assessment with sonography in trauma) to explore for free fluid.

In all hemodynamically stable patients, CT is the investigation of choice for identifying and characterizing splenic injuries.

Other options:

Option A- Courvoisier's sign is palpable gall bladder in the presence of jaundice due to periampullary carcinoma.

Option B- Cullen's sign is dark bluish discoloration around the umbilicus due to hemoperitoneum.

Option C- Ballance sign is a sign of splenic injury. Persistent dullness on the left side of the abdomen due to early coagulation of blood from the spleen is a positive sign. Shifting dullness can be present on the right side.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Spleen Injury Scale

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a history of sexual assault followed by amenorrhea. Her urine pregnancy test was positive. Which of the following is the most likely maturation index of her vaginal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The most likely maturation index of vaginal epithelium in a pregnant woman is 0/95/5.

The maturation index is also known as the karyopyknotic index. It is the ratio of mature squamous (superficial) cells to the intermediate and parabasal cells, expressed in percentage. It is expressed in three numbers expressing each of these cell types in percentages, in the format of parabasal cells/intermediate cells/superficial cells. 

Parabasal cells are round small and basophilic. Intermediate cells are transparent and basophilic. Superficial cells are thin, large, and acidophilic.

A significant shift in the maturation index can be seen from birth to menopause. It correlates with the hormonal status of the vaginal epithelium. In the proliferative (estrogenic) phase of the menstrual cycle, the ratio of superficial cells is more than 25 percent. And the ratio is low in the secretory (progestational) phase of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. Parabasal cells are predominant in the postmenopausal phase.

In pregnancy, the most likely maturation index is 0/95/5. During pregnancy, if the ratio of superficial cells is more than 10 percent it denotes the progesterone deficiency.

The most likely shift of the maturation index from birth to menopause is:

 Stage           Maturation index
(parabasal/intermediate/superficial)
At birth  0/95/5
Childhood    80/20/0
Reproductive period
preovulatory  0/40/60
mild secretory  0/70/30
pregnancy  0/95/5
postpartum    100/0/0   
Postmenopausal  100/0/0

questions.text: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib fractures. On examination, you notice a paradoxical movement of the chest, and the patient is diagnosed with respiratory failure. How would you manage him?

choices.text: Internal operative fixation of the fractures segments

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of flail chest with respiratory failure. Management of this condition is IPPV (intermittent positive pressure ventilation).

A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures i.e., 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. 

On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards, and therefore, less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards. This is known as paradoxical respiration.

The diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. 

Treatment:

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided.
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy.
  • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Treatment algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure:

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressively worsening pain, redness in the right eye for the last two days. She has a history of sarcoidosis. On examination, the right eye is inflamed around the cornea, the pupil is constricted, and reacts sluggishly to light. The iris appears muddy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressively worsening eye pain and redness, constricted pupil reacting sluggishly to light, muddy iris, and a history of sarcoidosis is likely to have anterior uveitis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disorder characterized by the formation of non-caseating granulomas. Anterior uveitis is often a presenting symptom of sarcoidosis.

Anterior uveitis presents with blurred vision, pain, photophobia, circumcorneal conjunctival injection (around the limbus) with an aqueous flare and keratin precipitates. The pupil is constricted and reacts sluggishly to light. The clear pattern of the iris is lost and it appears muddy.

In a slit-lamp examination, the following signs may be observed in anterior uveitis:

• Corneal signs: Presence of keratic precipitates.
• Anterior chamber signs: Hypopyon, presence of aqueous cells and flare, and a deep, irregular anterior chamber caused by posterior synechiae.
• Iris signs: Loss of the normal iris pattern, changes in color (commonly referred to as a “muddy iris”), and posterior synechiae.
• Pupillary signs: A constricted and irregular pupil, ectropion of the uveal pigment, and occlusion of the pupil (occlusion pupillae).

Steroids and cycloplegics are the mainstay of management for uveitis. Systemic therapy include steroids, NSAIDS and immunosuppressants.

Other options:

Option A: Acute bacterial conjunctivitis presents with pain, irritation, photophobia with hyperemia (pink eye), and purulent exudate. There is a diffuse conjunctival injection which is less seen in the circum-corneal region (as opposed to anterior uveitis)

Option C: Endophthalmitis is the infection of the intra-ocular cavities which presents with severe pain, loss of vision, and lid edema. It is usually seen in post-operative cases of ocular trauma (exogenous) and patients hospitalized with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections (endogenous).

Option D: Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma presents with severe unilateral eye pain, associated with headache and loss of vision. The examination shows a red congested eye, corneal edema with a shallow anterior chamber, and a mid-dilated pupil.

questions.text: X-ray of a patient who had a history of RTA appears as below. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and right tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with right lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse and left tracheal shift
Right pneumothorax with left lung collapse  and right tracheal shift

questions.solution:
The image shows a right pneumothorax with collapsed right lung and tracheal deviation to the left.

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space. When there is a progressive accumulation of intrapleural gas in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration) it is called a tension pneumothorax. It can result in the compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

It is characterized by:

  • Chest pain.
  • Tachypnoea, and acute dyspnea.
  • Sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness).
  • Neck vein distention.
  • Tracheal deviation away from the side of the injury.
  • Decreased chest movements on the affected side.
  • Hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side.
  • Absence or decreased breath sounds on the affected side.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge.
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line.
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung. 
  • Lung collapse on the same side of the injury. Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may be seen.
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph).

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine film (common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. 

The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign. It may be the only indication of a pneumothorax in such patients.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes with complaints of swollen fingers, heartburn, and occasional joint pains. She gives a history of Raynaud's phenomenon. Physical examination reveals taut, thickened skin over her hands and fingers with limited mobility. Presence of which of the following antibodies will confirm your diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of anticentromere antibody (ACA) will confirm a diagnosis of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. 

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis Versus Limited Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis

Characteristic feature Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
Skin involvement

Rapid progression

Involvement of the skin areas proximal to the knees or elbows or over the anterior chest, trunk, or abdomen

Slow progression

Limited to face and skin distal to the elbows and knees

 

 
Raynaud’s phenomenon

Less severe

 

Short history 

More severe; commonly associated with critical limb ischemia.

Long history 
Musculoskeletal Severe arthralgia, carpal tunnel syndrome, and tendon friction rubs Mild arthralgia
Pulmonary manifestation Interstitial lung disease more common Pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) more common
Scleroderma renal crisis Occurs usually <4 years of disease onset Very rare
Calcinosis cutis Less common More common & prominent
Auto-antibodies Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70), anti-RNA polymerase III Anti centromere

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
The image is that of fluorescein angiography showing the "flower petal pattern," which is seen in cystoid macular edema (CME). The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer at the fovea.

CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

Cystoid macular edema:

Etiology:

  • Inflammatory: all causes of posterior uveitis
  • Degenerative: Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Vascular causes
  • Irvine–Gass syndrome: CME after cataract surgery as a postoperative complication

Clinical features:

Presents as a diminution of vision and fundus shows dull foveal reflex/absent foveal reflex.

Treatment: 

Depends upon the aetiology of CME

  • Intravitreal steroids
  • Intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)
  • Macular grid laser
  • Acetazolamide (for CME associated with retinitis pigmentosa)
  • Topical NSAIDs (nepafenac)

Other options:

Option a : Drusens are extracellular deposits found in between the retinal pigment epithelium and Brusch membrane. They are assosciated with age-related macular degeneration. 

Option d : Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stack pattern. The image is given below,

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with type B tympanometry curve is suggestive of serous otitis media secondary to adenoid hypertrophy. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion would be the most appropriate management.

Enlarged adenoids in children can present as nasal obstruction, rhinolalia clausa, recurrent acute otitis media, and serous otitis media. Adenoid facies, characterized by an elongated face, open mouth, teeth crowding, high arched hard palate, and pinched-in nose, may also be present.

Serous otitis media also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear cleft. 

Glue ear can occur either due to eustachian tube dysfunction (adenoid hyperplasia, chronic sinusitis or tonsillitis or rhinitis, cleft palate, tumors of nasopharynx) or due to increased secretory activity of the middle ear mucosa (allergy, unresolved otitis media, viral infections).

Glue ear is commonly seen in children aged 5-8 years and is associated with insidious onset of hearing loss (not exceeding 40 dB), mild ear aches, and a history of upper respiratory tract infections. Delayed or defective speech may also result from hearing loss.

Otoscopy shows: 

  • Dull and opaque tympanic membrane with loss of light reflex
  • Thin leash of vessels along the handle of the malleus 
  • Fluid levels and air bubbles can be seen when the tympanic membrane is transparent. 

The otoscopy image of serous otitis media is shown below:

The tuning fork test reveals a conductive type of hearing loss and audiometry reveals hearing loss in the range of 20–40 dB. The fluid accumulation in glue ear causes decreased mobility (compliance) of the tympanic membrane leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve or type B curve on a tympanogram.

Treatment is mainly aimed at the removal of fluid and preventing recurrence. 

  • Medical management includes decongestants, antihistamines, and antibiotics.
  • Surgical management is done if the condition cannot be controlled with medications. It includes myringotomy and aspiration of fluid with grommet insertion. Adenoidectomy and tonsillectomy may be required and are usually done at the time of myringotomy.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with confusion, and evaluation shows a serum calcium level of 16 mg%. What is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
With respect to the above clinical situation, the patient is possibly suffering from a hypercalcemic crisis and the next line of management is saline hydration. 

The stepwise approach to the clinical management of his condition would be as follows: 

Step 1: Confirming the diagnosis - The patient was suffering from a hypercalcemic crisis as inferred from the elevated levels of serum calcium (Normal 9-11 mg%). 

Step 2: Restoring normal hydration - Many hypercalcemic patients are dehydrated because of vomiting and/or hypercalcemia-induced defects in urine-concentrating ability. Therefore, hydration through the application of IV fluids, typically 200-500 ml/hr of normal saline should be administered to maintain a urine output of >100 ml/hr. 

Step 3: Currently, the use of loop diuretics is controversial and the recent updates suggest, the use of loop diuretics to be limited to hypercalcemic crisis associated with heart failure or renal failure. Calcitonin or bisphosphonates have emerged as the preferred drugs for hypercalcemic management after restoring normal hydration with IV fluids.

questions.text: Maddox rod test was performed on a patient complaining of crowding of words while reading for long hours. The test revealed the following. The most likely diagnosis would be ______.
questions.solution:
The given test is a Maddox rod test, and the pattern of the appearance of white light in relation to the red line denotes a case of left eye exophoria.

The Maddox Rod Test involves using a Maddox rod and a tangent scale to assess eye deviations. The rod consists of parallel cylinders that transform a point light source into a line image. During the test, the patient focuses on a light 6 meters away, and the optical effect of the cylinders causes the line to appear perpendicular to the rod’s orientation. Since the rod prevents fusion, it detects eye misalignments like heterophorias and heterotropias, but cannot differentiate between them. The test can measure horizontal, vertical, and, when paired with another Maddox rod, cyclo-deviations.
 

Interpretation of the Test: 

  • To test for horizontal deviations, the Maddox rod is placed in front of one eye (for this example, the left eye) with the cylinders in the horizontal direction.
  • The patient fixates a point source of light and then sees a vertical line with the left eye and white light with the right eye.
  • If the light superimposes the line, orthophoria is present.
  • In this example, as the light is on the left side of the line, it is an exo-deviation; and if the light was on the right side of the line, an esodeviation would be present.

 Orthophoria: perfect ocular alignment in the absence of any stimulus for fusion

 Hypophoria: downward imbalance

 Hyperphoria: upward imbalance

 Exophoria: outward imbalance

 Esophoria: small inward imbalance

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with frequent episodes of nose-bleeds. She also complains of frequent episodes of headache and fever. The following test is positive in this patient. Which of the given findings is least likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Cottle’s test which is positive in patients with deviated nasal septum. Septal perforation is not associated with DNS. Septal perforation usually occurs as a consequence of septal abscess.

Cottle's test: The cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.

DNS is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal obstruction: Deviated nasal septum may lead to obstruction of the nasal cavity at different levels based on the type of deviation.
  • Chronic sinusitis: Deviated septum causes obstruction to the ostia of the sinuses. This causes poor ventilation of the sinuses leading to sinusitis.
  • Middle ear infection
  • Epistaxis: There is drying of the mucosa over the deviated septum due to air currents. This leads to the formation of crusts which, on removal, cause epistaxis.
  • Anosmia: reduced airflow may lead to anosmia
  • External deformity: External deformities of the septum may be seen due to deviation of the cartilaginous or the bony part of the nasal septum. Deformity of the tip or columella may also be seen.

CT scan showing a deviated nasal septum is given below:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with difficulty breathing and swallowing. He is tall and thin, with arachnodactyly and a high-arched palate observed during the examination. A chest X-ray reveals widening of the mediastinum and a rightward displacement of the trachea. A transesophageal echocardiogram shows dilatation of the ascending thoracic aorta. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this patient’s management?

choices.text: Operative repair if diameter is >5 cm
Operative repair if diameter is >6 cm
Operative repair if diameter is >5.5 cm
Operative repair if diameter is >4 cm

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient of Marfan's syndrome with ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm. In case of Marfan's syndrome, ascending aortic aneurysm of 4-5 cm is taken up for operative repair. This is because of a higher rate of expansion of the aneurysm in these patients.

Management of thoracic aortic aneurysm:

Beta-blockers and angiotensin receptor antagonists to reduce the rate of expansion, especially in Marfan's syndrome.

Operative treatment is indicated in:

  • All symptomatic cases
  • Ascending aortic aneurysm- ≥5.5 cm in diameter or growth rate of >0.5 cm/year
  • Descending aortic aneurysm- >6 cm in diameter or growth rate of >1 cm/year
  • Marfan's syndrome- ≥4-5 cm in diameter

The given radiograph shows thoracic aorta aneurysm:

questions.text: What parameter does the yellow color tracing on the monitor shown below represent?
questions.solution:
The yellow color tracing shown in the monitor is capnography.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. 

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both the inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:
  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic man comes in with symptoms of increasing pain in his forehead, swollen right eyelids, photophobia, and vesicles around his right eye, as shown in the picture below.  What treatment is most appropriate for him?
questions.solution:
This patient's growing pain around his left eye, together with the formation of several vesicles or pustules, suggests herpes zoster ophthalmicus, which is treatable with oral acylovir. Steroids are generally avoided in patients with herpes zoster because of the risk of further immunosuppression unless there is progressive ptosis, third nerve palsy or optic neuritis.

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus describes the reactivation of the varciella zoster virsus in the area supplied by the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and accounts for around 10% of cases of shingles. It can be adequately treated with the help of oral acyclovir at a dose of 800mg for a period of 7 to 10 days.

Features of herpes zoster ophtalmicus incude a vesicular rash around the eye which may or may not include the eye itself as well as hutchinson's sign which is rash developed on the side of the nose and indicates nasociliary involvement. Patients with with involvement of the nasociliary nerve have a stronger risk of developing herpes zoster ophthalmicus.

Guidelines to be kept in mind while treating patients with herpes zoster ophtalmicus include :

  • Treatment initiation within 4 days of onset of rash.
  • Intravenous antivirals may be tried in case of severe infection or if patient is immunocompromised.
  • Pain can be addressed with NSAIDs and if uncontrolled opioid analgesics may prove beneficial.
  • Systemic steroid can be tried in patients with progressive ptosis, occulomotor nerve palsy and optic neuritis as a means to retard secondary inflammation.

questions.text: The image shown below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an exclamation mark hair sign which is a characteristic feature seen in Alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes nonscarring patches of hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed patients.

The most characteristic lesion initially is a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia which has short extractable broken hairs called exclamation mark hair.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with telogen effluvium demonstrate empty follicles and regrowing hairs of normal thickness on dermoscopy.

Option C: Netherton syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. Patients with this disease present with lustreless, dry, short hair. On trichoscopy, patients may have a characteristic bamboo hair defect due to the collapse of the distal hair shaft into the proximal hair shaft secondary to defective keratinization.

Option D: Primary cicatricial alopecias are inflammatory disorders that lead to permanent hair loss

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes in with low back pain that has lasted for six months. During the examination, both his ankle and knee jerk reflexes are absent. An MRI reveals a lumbar disc prolapse at the L3-L4 level. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario described, an elderly male has been experiencing lower back pain for the past six months and on examination, both knee and ankle reflexes are absent, and an MRI reveals a lumbar disc prolapse at the L3-L4 level. This is indicative of cauda equina syndrome secondary to the lumbar disc prolapse.

Compression of the lumbosacral nerve roots below the level of termination of the spinal cord that is L1-L2 results in cauda-equina syndrome (CES). Common causes of CES include ruptured lumbosacral intervertebral disc, epidural hematoma, vertebral fracture, and compressive tumor.

Patients with CES usually present with low back pain, asymmetrical weakness, variable areflexia, diminished sensation in the buttocks and posterosuperior thighs, and perineal region in a saddle distribution. Rectal and bladder dysfunction, sexual impotence, absent bulbocavernous, patellar(knee), and Achilles(ankle) reflexes and variable amount of lower-extremity weakness. This reflects compression of nerve roots as they form the cauda equina after leaving the spinal cord. The majority of cauda equina tumors are primary tumors of glial or nerve sheath origin, metastases are very rare.   

Management includes starting dexamethasone immediately, radiation therapy plus glucocorticoids in case of spinal cord compression, and surgical decompression by laminectomy or diskectomy for disc rupture.

Note: Mass lesions in the lower spinal canal often produce a mixed clinical picture with elements of both cauda equina and conus medullaris syndromes.

Other options :

Option a : Conus medullaris syndrome is characterized by bilateral saddle anesthesia, and prominent bowel and bladder dysfunction. Also, anal and bulbocavernosus reflexes are absent.

Option b : Central cord syndrome results due to damage to the gray matter nerve cells and the spinothalamic tract crossing the central canal. Patients present with features are loss of pain and temperature sensation which are not seen in this patient. 

Option d : Brown-Sequard syndrome is a hemi-transection of the spinal cord. It presents with ipsilateral weakness (corticospinal tract), ipsilateral loss of position, vibration sense (posterior column), and contralateral loss of pain and temperature one or two levels below the lesion.

Related Pearl: Conus medullaris syndrome vs Cauda equina syndrome

 

Conus medullaris syndrome

Cauda equina syndrome
Injury

Vertebral column injuries between T12 and L2

 Vertebral column injuries distal to L2
Pathophysiology

Upper and lower motor neuron involvement

 Lower motor neuron involvement
Motor strength 

Symmetrical motor impairment 

 Asymmetrical motor impairment
Reflexes Knee jerk preserved, ankle jerk affected Both knee and ankle jerk affected
Sphincter dysfunction Urinary retention presents early in the disease course Urinary retention presents late in the disease course
 

Absent bulbocavernosus reflex
 

Radicular pain and low back pain

questions.text: What is the most common complication of Nissen's fundoplication?
questions.solution:
The most common complication of Nissen’s fundoplication is gas-bloat syndrome. 

Fundoplication is the procedure in which the fundus of the stomach is wrapped around the lower end of the esophagus.

After this procedure, most patients are unable to belch gas from the stomach into the esophagus. This causes increased gas in the stomach resulting in bloating sensation, abdominal discomfort, and flatulence. This is known as gas bloat syndrome and occurs more commonly with Nissen total fundoplication.

Pneumothorax is the most common complication that occurs intraoperatively.

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.solution:
The true statement is that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source in brachytherapy.

Radiotherapy is a common treatment modality for various cancers, including endometrial carcinoma. It works by targeting rapidly dividing cancer cells with ionizing radiation, which can damage the DNA of these cells and lead to cell death. Radiotherapy can be delivered externally (external beam radiotherapy) or internally (brachytherapy). In brachytherapy, radioactive sources are placed within or adjacent to the tumor, leading to a high radiation dose delivered directly to the tumor while minimizing damage to surrounding healthy tissue.

Stage III and IV of endometrial cancers are not operable. They are treated with brachytherapy followed by external radiation. Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed close to the tumor. 

Other options:

Option B: Larger blood vessels are more radioresistant than microvasculature.

Option C: Permanent non-dividing cells are more radioresistant than rapidly proliferating cells.

Option D: Small intestinal epithelial cells (intestinal crypts), which divide rapidly with no differentiation are the most radiosensitive.

questions.text: Two brothers were arguing over a property dispute when the elder of the two complained of chest pain and collapsed. His family says he was previously healthy and there was no similar disease in the family members. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The question describes an incident of sudden heart failure in a previously healthy man, under a stressful situation. The most likely diagnosis is Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy also called apical ballooning syndrome, or stress-induced cardiomyopathy occurs typically in older women after sudden intense emotional or physical stress. The ventricle shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction. Its shape resembles a Japanese jar used to trap octopuses, hence the name. The patients can present with pulmonary edema, hypotension, and chest pain and the ECG changes can mimic myocardial infarction. Coronary angiography, therefore, may be needed to rule out coronary occlusion. 

Treatment - It is a self-limiting disorder resolving within days to weeks. The prognosis is generally good.

The image above shows left ventriculography with the characteristic Takotsubo ventricle.

Other options :

Option a : Infective cardiomyopathy is most commonly associated with viral infections and the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is associated with Chagas' disease. Acute viral myocarditis often presents with symptoms and signs of heart failure, although it can also manifest as chest pain and show electrocardiogram (ECG) changes resembling pericarditis or acute myocardial infarction. In Chagas' disease, specific features include abnormalities in the conduction system, particularly dysfunction of the sinus node and AV node, as well as the right bundle branch block.

Option c : Acute myocardial infarction is characterized by localized ST-segment depressions or elevations with T wave inversions. 

Option d : Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy causes asymmetric septal wall thickening and commonly presents with symptoms of left ventricular outflow tract obstruction such as syncope, dyspnoea, and chest pain.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presented with knee pain. The x-ray of his knee joint is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the x-ray showing a lytic lesion at the end of a long bone with a soap-bubble appearance suggest a giant cell tumor (GCT)/ osteoclastoma. 

Osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years with slight female predominance. It affects the ends of long bones, involving metaphysis/epiphysis of long bones. GCT is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

Important X-ray features of a GCT:

  • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
  • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
  • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
  • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
  • No calcification within the tumor.
  • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor.

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue.

The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma:

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like the distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

Other options:

Option A: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumor that usually appears as well-circumscribed round or oval lytic lesions in the center of the epiphysis of a long bone. It presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. It is most commonly seen in ages 10-20 years.

The following is an x-ray image of the knee showing chondroblastoma:

Option B: Osteochondromas are common benign bone tumors commonly present in adolescents. The lesions consist of a bony mass, often in the form of a stalk, produced by endochondral ossification of a growing cartilaginous cap. They are usually painless. The common sites of involvement are the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.

The following is an x-ray image of the knee showing osteochondroma of the distal knee:

 

Option D: Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion which often occurs in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia is associated with McCune-Albright syndrome.

Radiological findings include:

  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy ground glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur

The given image shows the common locations of various bone tumors:

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except:

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Pansystolic murmur is not a physiological change in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in pregnancy:

Clinical examination

  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • Occasional S3at Mitral area
  • Aortic or pulmonary flow murmurs at aortic/pulmonary areas
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • S1 M increased and widely split

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Pregnancy does not alter voltage
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and
  • Increased left ventricular mass

Other options:

Option A: There is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG) as the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy.

Option B: Mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.

Option C: Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.solution:
Measurement of Troponin is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours.

Troponin T and Troponin I

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and the skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.

Creatine kinase (CK)..

  • If it is the only assay available, it can be used, but it is far less sensitive and specific than troponin.

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

  • Normally, serum levels of LDH2 is greater than those of LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1 is more than LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.
