questions.text:
A 40-year-old female patient had undergone a Pap smear test whose reports show LSIL (Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion). What would be the next step of management in the given scenario?

HPV- Human Papilloma Virus

LLETZ- Large loop excision of the transformation zone
questions.solution:
HPV testing is the next step of management in a woman aged ≥ 30 years whose Pap smear cytology report shows LSIL.

In women aged ≥ 30 years with cytology showing LSIL, HPV-testing is done. If HPV test comes positive, further management is with colposcopy with biopsy. If the HPV test comes negative, both the Pap smear test and HPV test (co-testing) are repeated after one year. 

If either the HPV test or the cytology report comes positive after one year, a colposcopy with biopsy will be done. Whereas a negative report warrants another co-testing at 3 years. Co-testing at 3 years will be followed by 5 yearly routine screening or colposcopy with biopsy based on the results.

However, LSIL in women < 30 years will be further proceeded by annual repeat cytology for two years. 

Cytology

(Betheseda

system) 

 Age Management
ASCUS < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
ASCUS ≥ 30 years

HPV testing, Cytology at 1 year
LSIL < 30 years Annual repeat cytology for 2 years
LSIL ≥ 30 years HPV testing

ASC-H 

HSIL

 < 30 years

Colposcopy ± biopsy

ASC-H/ HSIL

 ≥ 30 years

Colposcopy with cervical biopsy and endocervical assessment

ASCUS - Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

LSIL - Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

ASC-H - Atypical squamous cells: cannot exclude High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL - High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

With the biopsy/ histology report, cervical dysplasias are graded as 

Grade Description
Mild dysplasia (CIN I) Dysplastic cells in lower 1/3 of epithelium
Moderate dysplasia (CIN II) Dysplastic cells up to 2/3 of epithelium
Severe dysplasia (CIN III) Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of epithelium or the entire thickness of the epithelium

Mild dysplasia/CIN-I can be treated with ablation, if persisting for more than 2 years. CIN-II and III are usually managed with therapeutic conization, Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP), ablation of the transformation zone, etc.

Other options:

Option A: Conization is an invasive procedure where the cervix is cut in a cone-shaped manner. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It is indicated for diagnosis in women with HSIL or adenocarcinoma in situ.

Option C:  LLETZ (Large loop excision of transformation zone) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). This procedure is also known as Loop electro surgical excision procedure (LEEP).

Option D: Hysterectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the uterus. It's commonly performed to treat various conditions, including uterine fibroids, endometriosis, and certain cancers.

questions.text: Phlegmasia alba dolens refers to_______

choices.text: Extensive DVT of deep veins only
Extensive DVT of deep veins and collaterals

questions.solution:
Phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD) refers to extensive DVT of deep veins only.

Phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD) and phlegmasia cerulea dolens (PCD) are conditions that result from acute, massive deep vein thrombosis of the lower extremities. 

Phlegmasia alba dolens also called milk leg. It involves thrombosis of major deep venous channels of the extremity, sparing collateral veins. There is an absence of limb ischemia. The venous drainage is decreased but still present. It is characterized by pain and edema without cyanosis.

Phlegmasia cerulea dolens is extensive DVT of deep venous channels of the lower extremity with the thrombosis extending to collateral veins. It is characterized by pain and pitting with associated cyanosis. (PCD=Cyanosis). 

The image below shows cyanosis of the left leg depicting phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

questions.text: Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for condition X involving the female reproductive tract, the lesion responsible for condition X is located at?
questions.solution:
Marsupialization is an ideal treatment of choice for Bartholin cyst/abscess. The given clinical vignette is suggestive of leison of the Bartholin gland.  

Bartholin glands:

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. 

Clinical conditions :

  • Bartholin cyst: Caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation from infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision.
  • Bartholin abscess: An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess. It usually requires surgical drainage.

Pathology:

  • These commonly involve the duct and are most commonly sexually transmitted. Infection is generally polymicrobial.

Clinical features:

  • If the size is big, it might cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Analgesics for pain
  • Antibiotic for combating infections.
  • Specific treatment include Marsupialization, Incision and drainage with word catheter placement and Bartholinectomy.

Notes:

In any woman above the age of forty with recurrent Bartholin cyst, a suspicion of Bartholin gland cancer should arise and the cyst wall should be sent for biopsy.

questions.text: A patient’s arterial blood gas was consistent with the curve X in the nomogram given below with serum Na: 138 mEq/L, serum Cl: 110 mEq/L and serum HCO3-: 19 mEq/L. Which of the following can be a differential diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario shows a normal gap (hyperchloremic) metabolic acidosis, characteristic of RTA (renal tubular acidosis).

The anion gap in this patient can be calculated as Na+ – (Cl- + HCO3-) = 138– (110+19) = 138 - 129 = 9.

The normal anion gap ranges from 6 to 12 mmol/L, with an average of 10 mmol/L. Among the given options, only renal tubular acidosis is associated with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

All of the other options cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Methanol
  • Uremia (chronic kidney failure)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol, Propylene glycol
  • Infection, Iron, Isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates

Other options :

Option a : Aspirin overdose results in initial hyperventilation and respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of respiratory centres. In addition, aspirin being a salicylate causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option c : The most serious acute adverse effect of acetaminophen(Paracetomol) overdose is hepatic necrosis which can be fatal. N-acetylcysteine is considered as a definitive antidote for acetaminophen poisoning to prevent hepatic injury.

questions.text: Which of the following events in Rh-negative patients does not require Anti-D prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum hemorrhage is not an indication of Anti-D prophylaxis.

Anti-D prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative patients in the following circumstances:

  • Pregnancy loss due to:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Spontaneous abortion/hydatiform mole
    • Elective abortion
    • Fetal death (any trimester)
  • Procedures:
    • Amniocentesis
    • Chorionic villus sampling
    • Fetal blood sampling
    • External cephalic version
  • Delivery
  • Trauma
  • Placental abruption
  • Unexplained vaginal bleeding during pregnancy

questions.text: Following appearance on IVP is  seen in______
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign in the given IVP depicts cobra head/ adder head deformity seen in bilateral ureterocele.

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of the ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg (not <375) is an indication of mechanical ventilation.

Indications of mechanical ventilation:

Directly measured indices

  • Arterial oxygen tension <50 mmHg on room air
  • Arterial CO2 tension >50 mmHg in the absence of metabolic alkalosis

Derived indices

  • PaO2 /FiO2 ratio <300 mm Hg
  • PA–aO2 gradient >350 mm Hg
  • Vd/Vt >0.6 (Ratio of physiologic dead space over tidal volume)

Clinical indices

  • Respiratory rate >35 breaths/min

Mechanical indices

  • Tidal volume <5 mL/kg
  • Vital capacity <15 mL/kg
  • Maximum inspiratory force > −25 cm H2O

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient who is known to have chronic kidney disease is planned for dialysis treatment. Which of the following is not an indication for dialysis ?
questions.solution:
Severe coagulopathy is a relative contraindication for dialysis. 

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy. Here the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes, and toxins.

Dialysis broadly has 3 types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis include: 

  • Refractory metabolic acidosis that has failed to respond to medical treatment
  • Refractory hyperkalemia 
  • Extracellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Uremic symptoms
  • eGFR <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 
  • Any toxic ingestions

Note: Non-refractory hyperkalemia can be managed by: Restricting the dietary potassium intake, insulin, calcium gluconate or calcium chloride, inhalational β-agonist therapy and potassium binding ion-exchange resin.

Contraindications for dialysis include inability to secure vascular access, difficult vascular access, needle phobia, cardiac failure and coagulopathy.

 

Related Pearl: Hemodialysis vs Peritoneal dialysis

Difference between Hemodialysis and Peritoneal dialysis

Hemodialysis Peritoneal dialysis
Comparatively difficult access Easy access
Better clearance Good clearance
Short time for treatment Longer time may be required
Based on :

Solute removal through a semi-permeable membrane.

Based on principle :

Solute removal through a peritoneal membrane
Have to leave home Can be done at home
Complications:
  • Hypotension
  • Disequilibrium syndrome
  • Muscle cramps
  • Anaphylaxis reaction

Complications :

  • Peritonitis
  • Catheter-associated non-peritoneal infections
  • Weight gain
  • Metabolic disturbances
  • Residual uremia

questions.text: A 37-year-old male with a long history of chronic alcoholism presents with abdominal swelling, as shown in the image. Ultrasound of the abdomen reveals a shrunken liver, and Doppler studies indicate blood flow in the veins moving away from the umbilicus. The hepatic venous pressure gradient is elevated. Which of the following is not a complication typically associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests alcohol-associated cirrhosis, with dilated veins known as caput medusae resulting from Portal hypertension  and acanthosis nigricans is not a typical complication of portal hypertension. Common complications include esophageal varices with bleeding, hypersplenism (splenomegaly) and ascites.

Caput medusae refer to the dilated superficial veins that are present around the umbilicus. It is one of the major sites of portocaval anastomoses in portal hypertension, where these anastomoses open up to form dilated veins radiating from the umbilicus.

Portal hypertension is characterized by an elevated hepatic venous pressure gradient. The usual complications of portal hypertension are esophageal varices with variceal bleeding, hypersplenism (splenomegaly), and ascites.

The most common cause of portal hypertension is liver cirrhosis. Liver cirrhosis causes increased resistance to blood flow within the liver resulting in elevated portal pressure.

Clinically, patients with alcoholic liver disease present with jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider naevi, finger clubbing, asterixis, gynecomastia, and Dupuytren's contracture.

The illustrated image given below shows caput medusae around the umbilicus:

 

Acanthosis nigricans is associated with NASH(Non alcoholic steatohepatitis), due to insulin resistance.

The image below shows the direction of subcutaneous venous flow in various conditions:

questions.text: A 37-week primigravida has mild labor pains for 20 hours and the cervix is persistently 1 cm dilated but non-effaced. What would be the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of either false labor pain or prolonged latent phase. The appropriate management is to sedate the patient and wait.

False labor can be differentiated from the latent phase of labor by therapeutic rest i.e., the patient is sedated with morphine.

Features True labour pains False labour pains
Cervical dilatation and effacement Present Absent
Pain Lower abdomen and back, radiating to thighs Lower abdomen only
Show Present Absent
Bag of water Formed Absent
Relief with enema No Yes

 

The first stage of labour has got two phases:

  1. Latent phase 
  2. Active phase 

The latent phase of labour is defined as the period between the onset of true labour pain and the point when the cervical dilatation becomes 3–4 cm. The normal duration of the latent phase of labour in a primigravida is about 20 hours (average 8.6 hours) and 14 hours (average 5.3 hours) in a multipara.

The active phase has got three components:

  1. Acceleration phase with cervical dilatation of 3–4 cm.
  2. The phase of maximum slope of 4–9 cm dilatation.
  3. The phase of deceleration of 9–10 cm dilatation.

Other options:

Option B) Augmentation with oxytocin is done only in those patients who even after therapeutic rest continue to be in prolonged latent phase.

Option C) There is no indication of the cesarean section unless cephalopelvic disproportion is present.

Option D) Amniotomy is not useful and should be avoided in patients with prolonged latent phase.

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman at 37 weeks gestation presented with rupture of membranes 14 hours ago. Rectal culture for GBS performed at 36 weeks gestation is negative. She was treated for GBS bacteriuria at 10 weeks. Which of the following should be recommended for further management?

GBS: Group B Streptococcus

choices.text: Monitor and proceed with routine care
Repeat GBS culture from rectum and vagina
Perform cesarean delivery to prevent vertical transmission of GBS

questions.solution:
Intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis is recommended for mothers with a history of GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy, regardless of treatment for the same.

GBS (Streptococcus agalactiae) is a leading infectious cause of morbidity and mortality among newborns. Maternal GBS infection ranges from asymptomatic colonization to maternal bacteriuria, pyelonephritis, osteomyelitis, postpartum mastitis, and puerperal infections. GBS can overcome protective cervical mucus barriers during pregnancy and cause ascending antenatal infections. In infants, early-onset GBS infection (<7 days after birth) often presents as neonatal sepsis whereas late-onset disease usually manifests as meningitis between 1 week to 3 months after birth. Hence maternal intrapartum antibiotic administration is important for the prevention of early-onset GBS disease.

American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommends universal vaginal-rectal culture screening for GBS at 36 to 38 weeks gestation. It is followed by intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis for women identified to be carriers. The recommended regimen is Penicillin G IV, an initial dose of 5 MU (million units), followed by 2.5-3 MU IV every 4 hr continued until delivery.

Indications of intrapartum GBS prophylaxis:

  • GBS bacteriuria in the mother
  • Prior infant with invasive GBS disease
  • Positive GBS screening culture in the current pregnancy
  • Positive GBS status in a prior pregnancy
  • Unknown GBS status at labor onset with any of the following intrapartum risk factors:
    • Labor onset <37 weeks gestation (Preterm labor)
    • Membrane rupture for ≥18 hours
    • Intrapartum fever with temperature ≥100.4° F (38.0°C)
    • Intrapartum NAAT result positive for GBS

Intrapartum GBS prophylaxis is not indicated when:

  • Patients planned for cesarean delivery before the onset of labor or membrane rupture, regardless of GBS status or gestational age
  • Negative rectovaginal culture at ≥36 weeks gestation in current pregnancy
  • Unknown GBS status and intrapartum NAAT result negative and no intrapartum risk factors present

Other options: 

Option B: The patient requires Intrapartum penicillin prophylaxis and not just monitoring and proceeding with routine care.

Option C: This patient only underwent a rectal culture, and could benefit from a recto-vaginal culture. However, given that she had GBS bacteriuria in the current pregnancy, she must receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis regardless.

Option D: Prevention of vertical transmission of GBS is not an indication for cesarean section.

questions.text: A newborn presents to the outpatient department with a history of noisy breathing. Upon performing direct laryngoscopy, specific findings are observed. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the stridor in this infant?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor- e.g., laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor- e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor- e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A patient developed a loss of sensation over the root of the penis, following laparoscopic hernia surgery. Injury to which of the following causes this?
questions.solution:
Loss of sensation at the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

The iliohypogastric nerve (Option B) carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in a direct inguinal hernia. The iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy.

Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (Option C) results in loss of sensation in the skin of the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior thigh below the inguinal ligament.

The medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh (Option D) is a sensory branch of the femoral nerve. Injury to this nerve leads to loss of sensations over the areas supplied by this nerve, which include anterior-medial aspect of the thigh and knee.

questions.text: An elderly man who is a known case of laryngeal carcinoma is brought to the hospital with severe dyspnea and stridor. The patient suddenly desaturates and you decide to perform a tracheostomy. Which of the following would you prefer for this patient?

choices.text: Low tracheostomy, done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
Mid tracheostomy, done through the 3rd  tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 2nd tracheal ring
High tracheostomy, done through the 1st tracheal ring

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

High tracheostomy is done above the level of thyroid isthmus (Isthmus lies against II, III, and IV tracheal ring). The only indication for high tracheostomy is carcinoma of the larynx.

Functions: 

  • Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  • Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  • Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

The image shows a tracheostomy tube.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. The most likely diagnosis is ___________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls which is a type of posterior subcapsular cataract (after cataract).

Posterior subcapsular cataracts occur mainly due to ageing, other causes include the use of topical steroids, trauma, excessive consumption of alcohol, and exposure to ionizing radiation. Visual impairment is more during the day or exposure to bright light as the pupil constricts which blocks light rays.

After cataract also known as secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens.

Different types of after cataract include:

  • Elschnig’s pearls: where the subcapsular epithelial cells proliferate and develop into vacuolated soap bubble like clusters along the posterior capsule.
  • Soemmering’s ring: A peripheral dense ring is formed behind the iris and is enclosed between layers of the capsule.
  • Dense membranous after cataract: formed in the pupillary area impairing the vision.
  • Thin membranous after cataract: is thickened posterior capsule.

 

Treatment of after cataract is by, Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy of the posterior capsule which works on the principle of photodisruption, surgical posterior capsulotomy. 

 

Other options:

Option B: Irvine–Gass syndrome
Postoperative cystoid macular edema; delayed complication; clinically insignificant; resolves on its own

Option C: Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
Caused when an organism of low virulence (Propionibacterium acne or Staphylococcus epidermidis) becomes trapped within the capsular bag; characterized by pain and redness.

Option D: UGH syndrome 
Uveitis, Glaucoma, Hyphema occurring simultaneously; seen after anterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) implantation.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Image shows Babcock’s forceps where:

  • Distal part of distal blade is curved with a triangular fenestra which allows soft tissues to bulge out.
  • Tip is non traumatic with transverse serrations on it.
  • It has got a lock in proximal part.

Uses:

  • Hold any part of Bowel, Fallopian tube, Appendix, Ureter, Cord etc.

Option A: Allis tissue forceps

  • Distal blades are not opposing each other
  • Tip has got teeth in each blade which are opposing
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold Skin flaps, Fascia, Aponeurosis, Bladder wall.

Option C: Lane’s tissue holding forceps

  • It has got stout and thick distal blades with oval fenestra in each blade
  • Apposing tooth in the tip
  • Lock in proximal part

Uses:

  • Hold bulky and tough structures, hold lymph nodes.

Option D: Kocher’s hemostatic forceps

Apposing tooth in the tip and serrations in the distal blades.

Uses:

  • Hold pedicles, tough structures, cut ends of muscles
  • Hold ribs during rib dissection, hold gauze for blunt dissection, hold resected bowel.

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hysteroscopy with laparoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis of the likely uterine anomaly

For infertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy can detect müllerian anomalies, screen for co-existent endometriosis, and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathology. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus.

This approach can differentiate between a septate and a bicornuate uterus. On laparoscopy, the presence of a uterine fundus indicates that the uterus is septate, while absence indicates it is bicornuate. The capacity of each horn in a bicornuate uterus and the depth and thickness of uterine septum prior to surgical resection can also be assessed. 

MR imaging is the preferred imaging technique as it is highly accurate in the evaluation of müllerian anomalies. It clearly delineates both the internal and external uterine anatomy. Complex anomalies and common associations like renal or skeletal anomalies can be evaluated concurrently using MRI.

Other options:

Option A: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) provides information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity but cannot accurately visualize the external contour of the uterus. 

Option C: Laparoscopy alone as a diagnostic procedure cannot visualize the interior contour of a hollow viscus like the uterus. This can be done only with the help of hysteroscopy or imaging such as sonography, HSG, or MRI.

Option D: Transvaginal sonography is used for the initial detection of uterine anomalies causing infertility or spontaneous abortions. Complete evaluation of these anomalies is done by MR imaging.

questions.text: While performing urinary bladder catheterization, at what point should you stop advancing the Foley catheter and inflate the balloon to ensure proper placement?

choices.text: Bulb should be inflated as soon as urine begins to flow

questions.solution:
The bulb of the Foley catheter should be inflated once the catheter has been inserted almost to the hub - Point C. This ensures that the balloon is not inflated in the prostate, bladder neck, or urethra. The flow of urine alone may not be the surest sign that the tip of the Foley has reached the urinary bladder, since it can appear even at the level of the bladder neck.

Once the balloon is inflated, pull the Foley catheter out gently until it stops. The Foley catheter is now in the proper position. Make sure the drainage bag is properly attached and tape the Foley catheter to the abdomen. Bacitracin ointment is applied to the urethral meatus one to three times per day to prevent irritation from the catheter and urinary tract infection. If the patient is uncircumcised, the foreskin will need to be placed back into its original position.

questions.text: A patient who suffered an epileptic attack at home presented with pain over the left shoulder. An  AP view  X-ray of the shoulder was done, as shown below. Which of the following signs is seen here?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with a history of an epileptic attack, along with an X-ray showing a light bulb contour of the humeral head on the AP radiograph of the left shoulder, is indicative of posterior shoulder dislocation.

In posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus rotates internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views.

Other radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • The rim sign: Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm
  • The vacant glenoid sign: The glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it
  • The trough sign: A vertical line is seen on the anteromedial part of humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum   

Option A: Comolli's sign is seen in scapular fracture.

Option C: Destot's sign is seen in pelvic fracture.

Option D: Oliver's sign is seen in aortic aneurysm.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using the device shown below.

PEEP - positive end-expiratory pressure
questions.solution:
The correct statement regarding the oxygen delivery rate and the advantage of using high-flow nasal cannula is that it delivers oxygen at 40-60 L/min and increases positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

High flow nasal cannula is a mode of respiratory support used in the management of acute respiratory failure. It delivers humidified gas via the nasal cannula at high flow rates.

  • HFNC can deliver oxygen at 40L/min, 37°C, and 99.9% relative humidity.
  • The high-flow oxygen is delivered directly to the nasopharynx. This produces FiO2 equal to that delivered by traditional mask devices.

Advantages of using a high-flow nasal cannula are:

  • Soft and pliable nasal prongs provide comfort to the patient.
  • Warming and humidification of secretions: The heating of air to core temperature and humidification of the inspired air is better at high flow. The humidification causes increased water content in the secretions, which facilitates the removal of secretions. It also decreases the work of breathing and avoids airway desiccation and epithelial injury.
  • Reduces dead space: The high flow of the oxygen delivered clears the upper airway of the expired air, which reduces dead space by a decrease of rebreathing and allows a higher fraction of minute ventilation to participate in alveolar gas exchange.
  • Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP): HFNC increases the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and reduces the work of breathing.
  • High flow rate causes decreased entrainment of room air, allowing more accurate delivery of oxygen. 

The HFNC equipment shown in the image below uses a heated humidifier (named PMH200), a nasal cannula (no. 2), and a ventilator (brand: vivo30).

questions.text: Insall-Salvati index is associated with which of the following bones?
questions.solution:
The Insall-Salvati index is used for the determination of patellar height.

It is the ratio of the patella tendon length (LT) to the length of the patella (LP). It can be measured from a lateral radiograph of the knee.

  • Ratio between 0.8 and 1.2 - normal
  • Ratio above 1.2 - high lying patella (patella alta)
  • Ratio below 0.8 - low lying patella (patella baja)

The high and low-lying patella are usually associated with anterior knee pain and recurrent dislocations of the patella.

The image below is the radiograph of the knee showing the calculation of Insall-Salvati index.

questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they have been unable to conceive for more than a year. The lady has no abnormalities in her laboratory reports. The semen analysis report of her husband is given below. Which of the following findings indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia?

Appearance: Opalescent
Volume: 2 mL
pH: 7.5
Fructose: present
Sperm concentration: 14 million/mL
Morphology: 35% normal
Motility: 20% motile
No sperm agglutination was seen.
questions.solution:
The semen analysis finding of 20% motility indicates a diagnosis of asthenospermia.

Asthenospermia refers to decreased sperm motility. Normally, at least 50% of them should show progressive motility. Causes of asthenospermia include prolonged abstinence, anti-sperm antibodies, a genital tract infection, or varicocele.

Various semen abnormalities include:

An acidic pH or lack of fructose: indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.

A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction, or retrograde ejaculation.

Oligospermia is defined by a sperm concentration of <15 million/mL, concentrations of <5 million/mL are considered severe oligospermia.

Azoospermia (absence of sperm in semen) occurs due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas deferens, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.

Teratospermia or teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 32%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 75% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man undergoes pancreatic necrosectomy. The surgeon decides to place abdominal drains following the procedure. Which of the given suture materials is preferred for securing the drain externally?
questions.solution:
Silk sutures are commonly used to secure external drains.

Silk is a blue/black-colored, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva. Fibrous encapsulation of the suture occurs in 2 to 3 weeks, and it is absorbed slowly over 1 to 2 years.

It can be used for ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary. It can also be used for skin closure; however, there is an increased risk of infection and tissue reaction. It can be used for securing drains externally. Silk is not suitable for use with a vascular prosthesis or in tissues requiring prolonged approximation under stress. 


Other options:

Option A: Polydioxanone is a delayed absorbable suture material with a longer wound support period.

Option B: Monocryl (Polygylcaprone) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing in the skin. 

Option D: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material. It is one of the best sutures for vascular anastomosis.  It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure. Polypropylene mesh is used for hernia repair.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the given image.
questions.solution:
The image shows Hertel's exophthalmometer.

Exophthalmometry: measures protrusion of the apex of cornea from the outer orbital margin (with the eyes looking straight ahead).

An absolute protrusion of >20 mm or a difference of >2 mm between the two eyes is labeled as proptosis.

Instruments used to measure proptosis:

  • Luedde exophthalmometer
  • Hertel’s exophthalmometer: Most common instrument used. Its advantage is that it measures both eyes simultaneously.

Image: Luedde exophthalmometer

Other options :

Option a : Castroviejo caliper is used to calculate surgical distances within the eye. Its principal use is to measure the exact range for muscle resection during strabismus procedures.

Option b : A corneal trephine is a surgical instrument used to cut circular sections of corneal tissue or bone. It is used for a variety of procedures, including penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) and lamellar keratoplasty (LKP).

Option d : Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer. The principle behind its use is that the plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye. It is used to measure intraocular pressure (IOP). The image is givenn below

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and breathlessness. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His ECG is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature and the ECG are pointing towards the diagnosis of Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia.

Identifying features in ECG:

  • Heart rate > 100
  • Irregular rhythm
  • Discrete P waves with more than 3 different morphologies (black arrows)
  • Variable PR interval
  • Narrow QRS complex

Multifocal AT (MAT) is characterized by at least three distinct P-wave morphologies with rates typically between 100 and 150 beats/min.

It is the most common arrhythmia seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). It is also seen in hypoxia and pulmonary hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) (ECG given below)

Rhythm is regular. The rate is 150-200 bpm. P wave may be buried in the QRS complex. PR interval may not be possible to measure. Narrow QRS complex. PSVT can occur in a normal heart. The drug of choice for PSVT is adenosine.

Option B: Atrial fibrillation (ECG given below)

Rhythm is irregularly irregular. Rate is >300 bpm. P wave is absent, these irregular waves are known as fibrillation waves, which are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Atrial flutter (ECG given below)

Rhythm is regular. Rate is 250-300 bpm. Normal P waves are replaced by saw tooth shaped waves known as flutter waves.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use stopped drinking. Three days later, he was brought to the emergency department with disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of a chronic alcoholic man brought in with complaints of disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is precipitated by conditions like hepatitis and pancreatitis. It usually resolves in one week. The characteristic clinical features include:

  • Clouding of consciousness with disorientation in time and place
  • Distractibility and lack of attention
  • Visual, auditory, and/or tactile hallucinations
  • Autonomic disturbance with tachycardia, fever, hypertension, sweating, and pupillary dilatation
  • Psychomotor agitation and ataxia
  • Insomnia
  • Dehydration with electrolyte imbalance

Delirium tremens is treated using benzodiazepines starting with a higher dosage which is gradually tapered as withdrawal symptoms disappear. In cases of chronic alcohol use, vitamin deficiency (especially thiamine) may be co-existing and hence bolus doses of thiamine are given to prevent/treat Wernicke encephalopathy.

Other options:

Option A- Alcoholic hallucinosis is characterized by the presence of hallucinations (usually auditory) during partial or complete abstinence. However, the other symptoms given in the clinical scenario are not seen.

Option B- Korsakoff’s psychosis: It is seen n patients with chronic alcohol use usually followed by Wernicke’s encephalopathy, together referred to as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Patients with Korsakoff's psychosis present with memory disturbances, which is not seen in the given case.

Option C- Marchiafava-Bignami disease is a rare disorder seen in chronic alcoholics, associated with epilepsy, ataxia, dysarthria, hallucinations, spastic limb paralysis, and deterioration of personality and intellectual functioning.

Related Pearl: Alcohol Withdrawal Syndrome

Manifestation
Symptoms/signs

Tremulousness
Continuous tremor of > 8 Hz (or) Bursts of tremor activity < 8 Hz

Visual, auditory or tactile; intact orientation; stable vital signs.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is the most likely diagnosis in a postpartum woman with tearfulness, mood swings, and insomnia from day 4.

Postpartum blues, also known as baby blues, is a transient mood disorder characterized by sadness, tearfulness, confusion, and dysphoria. There are no suicidal thoughts or thoughts of harming the baby. These symptoms typically develop 3-5 days after delivery. They are thought to be due to hormonal changes, the stress of giving birth, and the responsibilities of motherhood. They resolve spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed if symptoms persist for >2 weeks to evaluate postpartum depression.

Other options:

Option A: Postpartum depression is when the symptoms of depressed mood, anxiety, insomnia, and weight changes persist for >4 weeks as per DSM 5 or >6 weeks as per ICD 11. The onset is within 4-6 weeks post-delivery. The patient may have occasional thoughts of harming the baby and suicidal thoughts. It can persist for months to years when untreated.

Option C: Postpartum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency that usually occurs within 4 weeks after delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks after delivery (ICD 11). The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. Psychotic symptoms such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation are seen. Lithium, antipsychotics, and an antidepressant is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Postpartum anxiety is not defined by DSM-5. However, some platforms might describe postpartum anxiety as excessive or severe worry after childbirth.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 12 weeks from delivery and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

 0.1-0.2% Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense cravings for food. She eats large amounts of food, which is followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the given scenario of a 16-year-old girl with intense food cravings followed by self-induced vomiting is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is an eating disorder, often seen in young women. It is characterized by binge-eating episodes, followed by inappropriate, compensatory measures to stop weight gain, like self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, diuretics, enema, and emetic abuse. These binge-eating episodes occur at least once a week and are present for at least 3 months. The patient fears gaining weight and has a relentless drive to be thin. 

The weight is normal in most patients with bulimia nervosa. However, few patients may either be overweight or underweight. There is a risk of dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. 

Treatment modalities are cognitive behavioral therapy, psychotherapy, and antidepressants such as fluoxetine.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that is often seen between the ages of 10 and 30. Typical features are self-induced starvation, voluntary and unhealthy reduction in weight, intense drive for thinness, and fear of becoming obese. These symptoms are usually present for at least a period of 3 months. Associated features can include depression, anxiety, amenorrhea in females, hypothermia, and bradycardia. 

Option C: Atypical depression is a type of depression characterized by mood reactivity, which is brightening of the mood in response to positive events; significant weight gain or increase in appetite; hypersomnia; leaden paralysis; and/or interpersonal rejection sensitivity, resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment. 

Option D: Binge-eating disorder is the most common eating disorder. It is characterized by rapid intake of abnormally large quantities of food over a short period of time, even when not hungry. There are feelings of guilt about the eating episodes, but these patients do not compensate in any way following the episodes of binge.

questions.text: In which of the following cases is the drug given below contraindicated?
questions.solution:
The drug given in the image is Oxytocin, and it is contraindicated in the malpresentation of the fetus.

Uses of oxytocin:

  • To accelerate abortion and to stop bleeding following evacuation of the uterus
  • Used as an adjunct to induction of abortion along with other abortifacient agents (PGE1 or PGE2)
  • To induce labor by ripening the cervix before induction
  • Augmentation of labor
  • Following expulsion of the placenta as an alternative to ergometrine.
  • In active management of the third stage of labor
  • To minimize blood loss and control postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Oxytocin is involved in the regulation of preterm and term labor but the exact mechanisms are not fully understood.

Contraindications of Oxytocin-

  1. Hypersensitivity to the hormone itself or any part of its synthetic version 
  2. Vaginal deliveries that are in themselves contraindicated. These include:
  • Active genital herpes infection in the mother,
  • Vasa previa,
  • Complete placenta previa,
  • Invasive cervical cancer
  • Abnormal position (most notably including a transverse lie) 

Other options: 

Option B- Recent studies have shown that induction of labor with a modified oxytocin infusion is a safe and effective alternative for selected gravidas with heart disease where elective delivery is warranted. 

Option C- Oxytocin is used to induce or augment labor, including in some cases of premature labor when delivery is necessary. It's not contraindicated in this situation.

Option D- There's no specific contraindication for oxytocin use in hypothyroidism. Thyroid disorders don't typically interfere with oxytocin administration during labor.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the POP-Q classification system?

choices.text: Stage 4 involves complete eversion of the vagina
In stage 3, the leading point is 1cm above hymen
Five reference points are present in the vagina
The points above the hymen are described as plus

questions.solution:
Stage 4 of the pelvic organ prolapse quantification system involves complete eversion of the vagina.

The pelvic organ prolapse quantification system was described by the Interna­tional Continence Society and has the following features:

  • The hymen is taken as a fixed point 
  • Six reference points are measured, using a scaled spatula:
    • Two on the anterior vaginal wall 
    • Two on the apical vagina
    • Two on the posterior vaginal wall 
  • Three measurements: The genital hiatus, perineal body, and total vaginal length.
  • The points above the hymen are described as minus and points below as plus.

Staging of POP Q:

Stage Description
Stage 0 No descent of pelvic organs.
Stage 1 The leading edge of the prolapse is >1 cm above the level of the hymen.
Stage 2 The leading edge of the prolapse is <1cm proximal or distal to the hymen.
Stage 3 The leading point of prolapse is >1cm below the hymen but protrudes no further than 2 cm less than the total length of the vagina.
Stage 4 Complete eversion of vagina

questions.text:
A 42-year-old teacher presented for an annual checkup. On examination, prominent tortuous, dilated subcutaneous veins are present on the medial side of her lower leg with the CEAP classification C2a Ep As Pn. She is aware of her varicose veins and is asymptomatic. What is the next step in management?

CEAP - Clinical - Etiology - Anatomy - Pathophysiology classification of varicose veins
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mild asymptomatic varicose veins according to the CEAP classification. Therefore, the next step in management is compression stockings.

In addition, she has no venous complications like pigmentation, eczema, or venous ulcers. Thus, she can be initially managed with compression stockings. 

Compression stockings provide external pressure to the limb which compresses the veins and improves venous return. There are two lengths available - knee or thigh length. However, knee-length stockings are commonly prescribed as they have better compliance. 

They are useful for the initial management of varicose veins as they relieve symptoms and are a conservative approach. If the varicose veins become symptomatic or become visually distressing then non-conservative approaches described below can be considered. 

Other options: 

Option A: Radiofrequency ablation uses electromagnetic currents to destroy the vein without damaging the other structures. It can only treat junctional and truncal incompetence and not varicosities. 

Option B: Saphenopopliteal ligation is a surgical procedure where the saphenopopliteal junction is dissected with flush ligation. Alternatively, the small saphenous vein can also be ligated as proximally as possible. Sural nerve neuropraxia and common peroneal nerve injury are possible complications. 

Option C: Saphenofemoral ligation is a surgical procedure made where the great saphenous vein is ligated and stripped. There are complications associated with this procedure such as saphenous nerve injury and neovascularization due to trauma leading to reoccurrence. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease
