*The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

Telangiectases are less than 1 mm, reticular veins are between 1 and 3 mm, and varicose veins are greater than 3 mm measured in the upright position.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden painless vision loss in his left eye. He has had a similar episode before but his vision was quickly restored.  His fundus appears as shown below. Which of the following has no role in his management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the fundus picture showing a cherry-red spot is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Propranolol is a beta blocker used in the management of hypertension, but it has no known benefits in the management of CRAO.

Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Emboli having carotid artery or cardiac origin are the most common cause of CRAO. The risk factors for CRAO include, Heart disease, Carotid artery disease, Mucormycosis, Varicella infection, Radiation exposure, trauma. Clinical features include, Sudden painless loss of vision, Amaurosis fugax(transient monocular blindness that is due to ischemia). Direct pupillary reflex is absent and RAPD is positive.

Fundus examination shows:

  • Marked attenuation of arteries – thread like arteries
  • Interrupted blood flow in vein – cattle track appearance
  • Cherry red spot
  • Severe edema 
  • Retinal pallor

Treatment is to dislodge the emboli by suddenly decreasing the IOP by I/V acetazolamide or ocular massage. Ocular massage is considered the most effective method. Other treatment options include IV mannitol, vasodilators (nitrates), fibrinolytic therapy, or laser photo disruption in some cases. In cases of giant cell arteritis, steroids are beneficial.

Related Pearl: Important causes of cherry-red spots

  • Commotio retinae
  • Central retinal and cilioretinal artery occlusion
  • Metabolic storage diseases
    • GM1 gangliosidosis
    • Mucolipidosis type I (sialidosis)
    • GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease)
    • Farber disease
    • Niemann–Pick disease
  • Retinotoxicity due to specific agents, including quinine, dapsone, gentamicin, carbon monoxide, and methanol

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, two weeks postpartum after a normal vaginal delivery complicated by postpartum hemorrhage and requiring 3 units of packed red blood cells, presents with severe fatigue, inability to produce breast milk, blurred vision, and hypotension. Lab results show decreased ACTH and cortisol. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient’s symptoms of fatigue, inability to produce breast milk, and hypotension after postpartum hemorrhage strongly suggest Sheehan’s syndrome, the next best step in management is Immediate surgical decompression.

Sheehans syndrome is a condition caused by pituitary gland damage due to severe blood loss during childbirth. Her recent development of blurred vision over the past three weeks raises concern for pituitary apoplexy, which is hemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. Progressive vision loss in this context suggests compression of the optic chiasm by an expanding pituitary mass. Given the risk of permanent vision damage, the next best step in management is urgent surgical decompression to relieve pressure on the optic structures and prevent further complications.

Pituitary apoplexy is a hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction due to traumatic major blood loss. If this blood loss occurs during delivery, it's called Sheehan's syndrome. The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk for haemorrhage and infarction. 

It can present acutely with sudden onset of headache, nausea, visual deficits and in severe cases, severe hypoglycemia, hypotension and shock, CNS haemorrhage and death.
Also, it can present late with the following features:
  • Lactation failure due to prolactin deficiency
  • Amenorrhea due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH secretion 
  • Adrenal insufficiency due to low ACTH

Damage to the pituitary results in decreased production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) causing secondary adrenal insufficiency which in turn results in decreased cortisol levels. In secondary adrenal insufficiency, aldosterone production is relatively preserved as it is independent of ACTH. It is the most life-threatening complication.

Treatment is by hormone replacement - first glucocorticoids (Option c), later - thyroid hormone, sex steroids (Option a), vasopressin (Option b), and growth hormones are given.

If there is evidence of progressive visual loss, cranial nerve involvement, or loss of consciousness, immediate surgical decompression must be carried out.

questions.text: A male patient who presented with decreased vision is examined as shown in the image below. Which of the following value is measured by this procedure?
questions.solution:
The procedure performed in the given image is A-scan ultrasonography. It is used for determining the axial length of the eyeball and can be done by direct contact (as shown in the image) or by using a water bath over the eye (immersion ultrasonography).

The sound beam must be aligned with the visual axis for maximal precision. Each reflecting surface is represented by a spike on the oscilloscope monitor.

The power of an intraocular lens (IOL) is calculated by a biometer and the procedure is termed biometry.

The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called SRK (Sanders-Retzlaff-Kraff) formula, which is given below:

 P = A - 2.5L - 0.9K

Where,

  • P is the power of IOL.
  • A is a constant which is specific for each lens type.
  • L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm determined using the A-scan ultrasonography.
  • K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

The image given below shows a biometer. 

 

The image below shows A scan ultrasonography for determining the axial length of the eyeball.

 

Option B: Corneal thickness is measured by pachymetry (image below).

 

Option C: Corneal curvature is measured by keratometry or opthalmometry (image below).

 

Option D: Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry (image below).

Related Pearl: Important investigations related to the cornea

  • Pachymetry: To measure corneal thickness
  • Keratometry: To measure corneal curvature (of the anterior surface)
  • Corneal topography: To measure corneal curvature, shape, and thickness
  • Specular microscopy: To assess the corneal endothelium
  • Anterior segment ocular coherence tomography: To assess different corneal layers

questions.text: Soon after the administration of an epidural block with 1.5 % lignocaine with epinephrine, your patient went into bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea soon after the administration of an epidural block suggests accidental subarachnoid (intrathecal) injection resulting in total spinal anaesthesia.

Salient features of total spinal anesthesia:

  • Occurs following attempted epidural/caudal anesthesia if there is accidental intrathecal injection
  • Rapid onset, as the anesthetic required for epidural and caudal anesthesia, is 5–10 times that required for spinal anesthesia
  • High spinal anesthesia extends to involve cranial nerves
  • Accompanied by hypotension, bradycardia, apnea, and loss of consciousness

Prevention:

  • Careful aspiration for CSF (to rule out intrathecal placement) and blood (to rule out intravascular placement) before injecting the local anesthesia
  • Use of a test dose with lidocaine and adrenaline
  • Incremental injection techniques instead of a bolus dose

Treatment:

  • Maintaining an adequate airway and ventilation and supporting the circulation

Other options: 

Option A - Accidental subdural injection manifests after 15-20 minutes with features similar to a high spinal blockade.

Option C - Accidental intravascular injection manifests as systemic toxicity with CNS and CVS symptoms.

Option D - Allergic manifestation presents with hives, angioedema, and bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with amnesia. Which of the following will not be impaired in this patient?

choices.text: Name of pet bird growing up

questions.solution:
The ability to drive a bicycle will not be impaired in this patient with amnesia.

The ability to drive a bicycle is a non-declarative memory and non-declarative memory is preserved in amnesia.

Non-declarative memory includes:

  • Skill learning
  • Habit learning
  • Simple forms of conditioning

Declarative memory supports the conscious recollection of facts and events.

  • Memory for routes, lists, faces, melodies, objects
  • Memory for other verbal and nonverbal material

Memory of the melody of his favourite song, name of pet bird growing up and route navigation are all types of declarative memory.This is impaired in amnesia.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with fever for 3 days associated with chills and rigors. His temperature is 102°F. Cardiac auscultation shows a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region. His past history is significant for prosthetic valve surgery 2 years back. Which of the following organism is the most likely cause for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Patient developing endocarditis 2 years after prosthetic valve surgery suggests late-onset endocarditis. In such cases, the most common causative organism is streptococci.

Fever plus a new-onset systolic murmur in the mitral region with a history of prosthetic valve surgery is strongly suggestive of Infective endocarditis as the likely diagnosis. The etiology of Infective endocarditis (IE) includes Staphylococcus aureus as the most common bacterial cause. Healthcare-associated IE is typically due to S. aureus, coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS), and enterococci. For patients who have had prosthetic valve surgery within the past 12 months, CoNS are the most common pathogens, while in those who had surgery more than 12 months ago, Streptococcus is the most common cause.

Clinical features of infective endocarditis include:

  • Fever with chills, anorexia, weight loss, malaise, headache, night sweats, abdominal pain, and arthralgias
  • Cardiac murmurs, mycotic aneurysm, heart failure
  • Splenomegaly, splenic infarction, renal infarction, glomerulonephritis
  • Stroke, Meningitis
  • Vertebral osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and abscesses

Peripheral manifestations of infective endocarditis include the following:

  • Petechiae: Common but nonspecific finding.
  • Osler nodes: Tender subcutaneous nodules are usually found on the distal pads of the digits as shown below.

 

  • Janeway lesions: Nontender maculae on the palms and soles as shown below.

 

  • Roth spots: Relatively rare retinal hemorrhages with small, clear centers as shown below.

Other options-

Option B: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism causing infective endocarditis overall.

Option C: Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoS) is the most common group of organisms causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery).

Option D: HACEK organisms cause subacute infective endocarditis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with proteinuria, and hemoptysis, with the following clinical presentation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows saddle nose deformity, which occurs due to the destruction of the nasal septum. A history of proteinuria and hemoptysis along with the saddle nose deformity is suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis).

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic sinusitis, serous otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage, nasal septal perforation, and mucosal ulceration of the nasopharynx.
  • Lower respiratory tract: presenting with cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and persistent pneumonitis. Lung involvement typically appears as multiple, bilateral nodular cavitary infiltrates.
  • Kidneys: focal or segmental glomerulonephritis presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. If left untreated it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Apart from these organs, it can also affect the eyes and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Lab investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. Chest radiograph will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates. 

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from the lungs, upper airways, skin, and rarely in the kidneys. HPE shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and veins together with either intravascular or extravascular granuloma formation. Chronic nasal carriage of Staphylococcus aureus is associated with a higher relapse rate. 

Options A: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. Severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates characterize the pulmonary findings. Renal disease is less common in these patients.

Option B: Leprosy or Hansen disease is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by infection with Mycobacterium leprae. it can present as a deformity on the nose and nasal perforation but is often accompanied by crusting. It is also accompanied by skin symptoms like anesthesia and nerve involvement

Option C: SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. Clinical features include a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash), oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is Sims curette?
questions.solution:
The instrument marked as 1 in the image is Sims curette. 

It is a single-ended uterine curette used for dilatation and curettage.

It is designed to remove tough tissue from the lining of the uterus for biopsy or excision. The curette features a sharp loop tip to aid in the removal of uterine tissue.

 The image above shows the trolley with various instruments:

  1. Sims uterine curette
  2. Hegar dilator
  3. Sims uterine sound
  4. Karman's cannula - It is used for menstrual regulation. It can be identified by the whistle-like tip.
  5. Leech Wilkinson's cannula
  6. Rubin's cannula 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text: A 25 year old presents with yellowish discoloration of sclera with mild similar episodes in childhood. Lab investigations shows normal liver enzymes, raised urine bilirubin and normal urinary coproporphyrin levels (type I>type 3). Gall bladder on oral cholangiography was not visualised.Which of the following is the possible cause of jaundice in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario patient presenting with yellow discoloration of eyes and lab investigations showing raised urine bilirubin levels along with urinary coproporphyrin 1 more than 3 and normal liver enzymes is suggestive of Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS). 

Only conjugated bilirubin can appear in the urine because it is water-soluble and filterable by the kidney. Unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble and bound to albumin, hence it cannot be filtered by the kidney. Among the given options, Dubin Johnson syndrome has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Dubin Johnson syndrome (DJS) is an autosomal recessive condition causing defective expression of MRP 2 protein. MRP 2 is an ATP-dependent canalicular membrane transporter which is important for the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin. Defect in this protein is responsible for conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The patient has icterus but is otherwise asymptomatic. The icterus might get noticed only during illness, pregnancy or consumption of OCPs.

Liver biopsy shows an accumulation of dark melanin-like pigment in the hepatocytes. In DJS, there is Increased excretion of coproporphyrin 1 in the urine eventhough the total urinary coproporphyrin remains normal. LFT shows conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

 

Other options :

Option a : Hemolytic anemia is associated with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option b : Gilbert’s Syndrome is characterized by decreased UDP glucuronyl transferase activity leading to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can be autosomal recessive or dominant.

Option c : Crigler-Najjar syndrome type-I is due to the absence of UDP-glucoronyl transferase enzyme. It is an autosomal recessive hyperbilirubinemia syndrome characterized by severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and usually presents with kernicterus. It is usually fatal in the neonatal period.  

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

 Predominantly Unconjugated Hyperbilirubinemia  Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Excess production of bilirubin

  

Hemolytic anemias

Biliary tract obstruction

Resorption of blood from internal hemorrhage (e.g., alimentary tract bleeding, hematomas)

 Biliary tract diseases like primary biliary cirrhosis and primary sclerosing cholangitis

Ineffective erythropoiesis (e.g., pernicious anemia, thalassemia)

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Reduced hepatic uptake

Rotor syndrome

Drug interference with membrane carrier systems

  

Some cases of Gilbert syndrome

  

Impaired bilirubin conjugation

  

Physiologic jaundice of the newborn (decreased UGT1A1 activity, decreased excretion)

  

Breast milk jaundice (β-glucuronidases in milk)

  

Genetic deficiency of UGT1A1 activity (Crigler-Najjar syndrome types I and II)

  

Gilbert syndrome

  

Diffuse hepatocellular disease (e.g., viral or drug-induced hepatitis, cirrhosis)

  

Related Pearl: Rotor syndrome vs Dubin johnson syndrome

  Rotor syndrome Dubin Johnson syndrome
Inheritance Autosomal recessive Autosomal recessive
Defect Organic anion transporting polypeptide  defect.(OATP1B1,OATP1B3) Multi drug resistance protein (MRP )2 mutation
Biopsy Normal Black pigmentation
Conjugated bilirubin Elevated Elevated
Kernicterus absent absent

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman on thyroid treatment with drug “X” for 3 years was advised to switch medications during pregnancy but continued with “X” due to nausea from the new drug. After delivery, her baby developed the condition shown in the image. What drug was likely used by the patient?
questions.solution:
The given image showing aplasia cutis congenita of newborn is commonly associated with use of Methimazole in pregnancy.

Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that belongs to the group of thioamides. It acts to prevent hormone synthesis by inhibiting the thyroid peroxidase-catalyzed reactions - iodine organification and coupling of iodotyrosine residues. It does not inhibit the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. It is the drug of choice for Grave's disease.

Methimazole crosses the placenta to a greater degree than propylthiouracil. It is usually avoided in the first trimester due to methimazole-associated embryopathy including fetal aplasia cutis. Thus, when available, propylthiouracil should be used in the first trimester. Methimazole is used for the remainder of the pregnancy due to the concern for propylthiouracil-associated liver failure in pregnancy. 

Agranulocytosis is the most serious side effect of propylthiouracil and methimazole though the incidence is low. Development of sore throat or fever should be reported, the antithyroid drug should be discontinued, and an urgent complete blood count is obtained to confirm the presence of agranulocytosis. 

Other options:

Option b : Propylthiouracil is the preferred anti-thyroid drug during pregnancy especially till 14-16 weeks, because carbimazole and methimazole are associated with aplasia cutis (absence of skin, usually on the scalp). 

Option c : Propranolol is given to control adrenergic effects before the effect of anti-thyroid drugs takes effect fully.

Option d : Levothyroxine (T4) is used for the treatment of Myxedema coma and can be administered as a single IV bolus of 500 μg.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presented with lethargy, diarrhea, and darkening around the eyes. On examination, his blood pressure was elevated and a mass was palpated in the abdomen.  A biopsy from the mass is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with a mass in the abdomen, diarrhea, ecchymosis, hypertension, histopathology showing Homer-Wright psuedorosettes is suggestive of neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastoma is the tumor from the sympathetic nervous system in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic chain that originates from neural crest cells. The most common cause of familial predisposition is the mutation in the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene.

It is predominantly seen in children less than 5 years of age. They present with a mass in the abdomen. Ecchymosis or proptosis due to secondaries in the periorbital region. Elevated blood pressure due to increased levels of catecholamines in the blood.

In children, neuroblastoma mostly arises from the adrenal medulla. Histology shows small round blue cells with dark nuclei and scanty cytoplasm and Homer-wright pseudorosettes.

Urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) are elevated. CT or MRI to assess the mass and secondaries.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor and adjuvant chemotherapy. The drugs used from chemotherapy are carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, etoposide, and doxorubicin.

The image below shows a typical Homer-wright pseudorosette is seen in which tumor cells are arranged concentrically with a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material:

Other options:

Option A- Hepatoblastoma is the most common childhood liver tumor. Histologically it is composed of small polygonal embryonal cells forming trabeculae, acini, or papillary structures in the developing liver.

Image below: Histology of hepatoblastoma showing proliferating hepatoblasts consisting of round epithelial type cells.

Option B- Rhabdomyosarcoma is a mesenchymal malignant tumor. Histologically it is composed of sheets of primitive round cells with skeletal muscle differentiation.

Image below: Histology of alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma showing sheets of primitive round cells.

Option C-  Nephroblastoma also known as Wilms tumor is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood. Histologically the classic triphasic pattern composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types is seen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of multiple miscarriages and recurrent venous thrombosis. Laboratory tests reveal a prolonged aPTT and positive anticardiolipin antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA). 

APLA is characterized by recurrent thrombosis due to the formation of autoantibodies. It generally affects women. APLA should be considered in those under the age of 55 with recurrent thrombosis. The presence of at least one clinical and laboratory criterion is required for diagnosis. 

Clinical criteria: 

  • Vascular thrombosis with one or more episodes of thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small vessel) in any organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    1. With the unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus after 10 weeks
    2. Premature birth of a morphologically normal fetus before 34th week due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more unexplained spontaneous abortions before the 10th week.

Laboratory criteria: 

  • Positive lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Positive anticardiolipin (aCL)
  • Positive anti-beta2GPI antibodies.

Treatment involves lifelong warfarin therapy titrated to a goal INR of 2.5-3.5. Aspirin may also be added at a dose of 80 mg. 

Other options: 

Option B - Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation in response to activation of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with LA. In addition, this patient has a chronic history of recurrent DVT and pregnancy loss. Elevated levels of fibrin degradation products are sensitive for diagnosing DIC

Option C - Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a form of systemic hypercoagulability that arises from the paraneoplastic syndrome because of procoagulant factors. There would be multiple venous thromboses that appear, disappear, and reappear in another location. 

Option D - Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia. It is a bleeding disorder and is not characterized by recurrent thrombosis. It is associated with recurrent bleeding into soft tissues, joints (hemarthrosis), and muscles as a result of trauma or spontaneous mechanism. Lab values show prolonged aPTT.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Hb - 6.9g/dL
  • WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
  • Serum calcium 13mg/dL
  • Creatinine 2.3mg/dL
  • Total protein 9g/dL
  • Albumin 2.4g/dL
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes an elderly woman with confusion, thirst and abdominal pain along with elevated serum calcium levels (hypercalcemia), elevated creatinine suggestive of renal failure, anemia and osteolytic bone lesions (CRAB features); and hypoalbuminemia with elevated total proteins. The most likely diagnosis is multiple myeloma (MM).

Multiple myeloma (MM) is a malignant plasma cell disorder characterized by clonal plasma cell proliferation, increased osteoclast activity, and suppressed osteoblast activity, leading to bone lesions and hypercalcemia. Common signs include bone pain, fractures, infections, anemia, elevated ESR, and normal ALP.

Diagnosis involves finding monoclonal immunoglobulin (M spike) on electrophoresis, Bence Jones proteins in urine, and rouleaux formation on a peripheral smear. MM is diagnosed based on ≥10% clonal plasma cells in the bone marrow or biopsy-proven plasmacytoma, along with myeloma-defining CRAB features (hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, or bone lesions).

Treatment includes a combination of lenalidomide/thalidomide (immunomodulatory agents), bortezomib (proteasome inhibitor), and dexamethasone. International Staging System (ISS) is used for assessing prognosis in multiple myeloma patients. Serum β2-microglobulin is the most important prognostic marker.

Other options:

Option A: The bony metastasis in breast carcinoma is usually osteolytic. However, CRAB features, hypoalbuminemia, and elevated total protein suggest multiple myeloma.

Option C: Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by hypercalcemia and low phosphorus but is not associated with anemia and hypoalbuminemia.

Option D: Milk-alkali syndrome occurs after ingestion of large amounts of calcium and vitamin D supplementation. It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrolithiasis.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

Raised [PTH]

Decreased [PTH]

Hyperparathyroidism

  • Primary (adenoma > hyperplasia)
  • Secondary
  • Tertiary

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

Vitamin D toxicity

 

Immobilization

 

Thiazide diuretics

 

Sarcoidosis

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

Plasma cell neoplasms and variants

Plasma cell myeloma
  • Non secretory: No secretion of Ig, No M component.
  • Smoldering: M protein in serum ≥ 3g/dL and/or ≥10% clonal plasma cells in bone marrow, and no related organ or tissue impairment.
  • Plasma-cell leukemia: >20% plasma cells in the peripheral blood or Absolute plasma cell count of >2 X 109/L.

Plasmacytoma
  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma.
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone.

Monoclonal immunoglobulin deposition diseases
  • Primary amyloidosis: Tumor secreting light chains that are deposited as beta-pleated sheet structure (amyloid light chain).
  • Systemic light and heavy chain diseases: Secrete abnormal light or heavy chain or both, which do not form beta pleated sheet, stain Congo Red or contain amyloid P component.

Plasma cell neoplasms with associated paraneoplastic syndrome

POEMS syndrome- Polyneuropathy, organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, Monoclonal gammopathy, Skin changes.

TEMPI syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The shown forceps have no catch and have fenestrated blades suggestive of ovum forceps.

Ovum forceps are used to remove the products of conception in dilation and evacuation without crushing the conceptus. Other uses are:

  • Removal of molar tissue from hydatidiform mole
  • Removal of small uterine polyp

Uterine wall injuries are minimal due to the absence of catch. It is introduced with the blades closed and then opened up inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement facilitates the detachment of the products from the uterine wall and also minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

The following image shows the ovum forceps. 

Other options:

Option A- Sponge holding forceps is used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during any abdominal or vaginal operations
  • Toilet vulva, vagina, and perineum prior to and following delivery
  • Hold the membranes if it threatens to tear during delivery of the placenta
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage procedures

The following image shows the sponge holding forceps. 

Option C- Lane's tissue forceps are used to:

  • Hold parietal wall for retraction during abdominal operations with transverse incision (hysterectomy)
  • Hold the polyp or fibroid in polypectomy or myomectomy surgery
  • Hold towel during draping

The following image shows Lane's tissue forceps. 

Option D- Allis tissue forceps are used to:

  • Catch the anterior lip of the cervix in a dilation and evacuation procedure
  • Hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during repair
  • Catch hold margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa during repair
  • Catch hold the torn ends of the external sphincter ani prior to suture repair of complete perineal tear

The following image shows Allis tissue forceps.

questions.text: The patient presented with the following appearance when asked to look straight. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows adduction of the right eye due to paralysis of the right lateral rectus, indicating right abducens (6th) nerve palsy.

6th nerve palsy 

  • The nucleus of the sixth (abducens or abducent) nerve lies at the mid-level of the pons.
  • Clinical features
    • Esotropia in the primary position due to relatively unopposed action of the medial rectus
    • Limitation of abduction on the side of the lesion
    • Normal adduction of the affected eye
    • A compensatory face turn is towards the side of the paralyzed muscle in unilateral palsy 

Other options :

Option a : 3rd or oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis due to weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris, abduction and depression in the primary position (due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique). Limited adduction, elevation and depression due to medial rectus, superior rectus and inferior oblique weakness. Pupil will be dilated pupil with defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

Option b : 4th or trochlear nerve supplies the superior oblique muscle and its palsy causes hypertropia, limited depression and extorsion of the affected eye. 

Option d :  Horizontal gaze palsy occurs due to a lesion in the parapontine reticular formation. This leads to ipsilateral lateral rectus and contralateral medial rectus weakness. It is characterized by the inability to look in the direction of the lesion. 

Related Pearl: Functional components of cranial nerves

Functional components of cranial nerves 
Oculomotor: CN-3
  • Extraocular skeletal muscles – GSE
  • Preganglionic fibres to ciliary ganglion - GVE
Trochlear: CN-4
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (SO)- GSE
Trigeminal: CN-5
  • Sensation from the face - GSA
  • Motor to 1st arch - Br E (SVE)
Abducent: CN-6
  • Extraocular skeletal muscle (lateral rectus)- GSE
Facial: CN-7
  • General sensory from ear - GSA
  • Special (taste) sensation - Br A
  • Motor to 2nd arch - Br E
  • Parasympathetic to submandibular and pterygopalatine ganglia - GVE
Vestibulocochlear: CN-8
  • Hearing/balance - SSA
Glossopharyngeal: CN-9
  • Sensory from pharynx/tongue – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • General sensation from ear – GSA
  • Parasympathetic to otic ganglion - GVE
  • Motor to 3rd arch - Br E
Vagus: CN-10
  • Sensory from ear - GSA
  • Sensory from pharynx/larynx – GVA
  • Taste - Br A
  • Parasympathetic ganglia in thorax/abdomen - GVE
  • Motor to 4th/6th arch - Br E
Accessory: CN-11
  • Motor to 6th arch (through vagus) - Br E
  • Motor to sternocleidomastoid and trapezius - GSE
Hypoglossal: CN-12
  • Motor to lingual muscles – GSE

abbr.

A - afferent , E - efferent , Br - Branchial (word special (derived from branchial arches) can also be used instead of branchial, but due to confusion with special sensory (carrying special senses) its better avoided), V - Visceral, G - General, CN - cranial nerve,  SO - superior oblique muscle.
